reviewText:
Qualifying Questions
1. Do you like story-based games like Telltale games or Quantic Dream games?
2. Do you like it when the gameplay isn't that difficult so it doesn't get in the way of the narrative?
3. Do you like having your mind screwed with?

If you answered yes to:
1 of those questions: Wait for a Steam sale but check it out
2 of those questions: Buy it if you're really looking for a new game to play right now
3 of those questions: Buy it right now


Find my full review here! https://youtu.be/klfWHLKz2YI

reviewText:
Get this. Get this and play it, preferrably all in one go. This is the first game in a while that kept me interested enough to complete it in one playthrough, albiet, I only completed one....storyline?

The plot is amazing, it is a mindfudge, it has great art, its just... good.
I originally got this as a palet cleanser, as something to play between some more in-depth games, but honestly, if I didn't have to work in the morning, I would continue playing this to get all the achievements available.

I should also mention, DONT LOOK UP PLAYTHROUGHS OR HINTS, this game is about playing on your own, about finding out about who you are a little more. I know that doesnt make sense, but you'll understand once you play this.

In short; if you like mystery, good artwork, building your own plot, deeper meanings behind things, being immersed in the story, and dont mind that youre not shooting, stabbing, or otherwise killing/maiming/destroying things, then play this. Do it. You wont regret it.

reviewText:
Can you walk and talk at the same time? If not, Oxenfree might not be the game for you because, for the majority of the game, that is all you will be doing. If warning lights are currently flashing in your brain and the phrase “walking simulator” is on the tip of your tongue, hold on for just a moment and let me explain why this game is worth your time.

Yes, Oxenfree is a narrative driven experience in the same vein as any Telltale game and yes, the game has very few mechanics to speak of. However, rather than using “walking simulator” to describe this game, I believe the label “conversation simulator” would be a much more appropriate choice, as this is the area where Oxenfree truly shines and sets itself apart from the rest of its genre. On the surface, Oxenfree’s dialogue system is comparable to that of Mass Effect or similar titles; every time your character Alex speaks, you are presented with three dialogue choices that appear in different colored bubbles above her head. I say three options, but there is actually a fourth: to not say anything at all (you can actually play through the entire game without speaking). Unlike in other games that allow dialogue choice, however, Oxenfree’s dialogue operates in near-real time; Alex will speak exactly when you tell her to, interrupting or talking over other characters. This makes conversations flow naturally without unnatural pauses and provides that real life conversation pressure of not wanting to interrupt someone who’s talking but also wanting to get to get your 2 cents in before the conversation moves on.

However, a good dialogue system alone does not a great conversation simulator make. What really sells Oxenfree’s dialogue is its flawless writing and voice acting. Unlike Life Is Strange, where teenage characters are speaking lines obviously written by adults trying to immitate a vernacular outside of their experience, Oxenfree’s teens sound wholly natural. Lines are delivered full of pauses, incomplete thoughts, “ums” and “ahs”, and the kind of grammatical errors caused by talking faster than your thoughts. Sometimes lines will also just slowly die off or end mid-thought. I’ve rarely seen dialgue written and delivered so realistically, especially for adolescent characters in a video game.

In my opinion, the game is well worth your time just the points I’ve listed so far. However, it would be unfair not to mention the rest of the game’s strengths! Firstly, its atmosphere. While Oxenfree may be marked as a horror game, I don’t think that label is appropriate here. While there may be one or two scenes that startle, Oxenfree’s soundtrack, visual design, and story combine to form an eerie supernatural thriller that is tense and head-scratching, rather than scary. And what a story it is! While it may start slow, using a clichéd horror trope of a group of teens spending a night in a remote location, the story quickly picks up and sucks you in. Characters are well rounded and detailed and the plot is paced well right up to its solid conclusion.

If I had any criticisms to level agains the game, most would be related to the way you move around Oxenfree’s island setting. Many areas of the game are proportioned to allow space for conversations to play out. However, there are many cases where you have to backtrack the way you came without the luxury of a conversation to keep your mind off of the characters’ glacial movement speed. I also encountered several conversation-related bugs that prevented me from progressing. Although your choices subtley influence the course of the game  (there are no “Telltale will remember that.” cues), Oxenfree plays out largely the same over multiple playthroughs, giving it a lower replay value. Due to this fact and its short, 3 hour runtime, you may rightly decide to invest your money elsewhere. However, if you’re looking for a tight, well-delivered narrative experience that you can finish in an afternoon, Oxenfree might be just what you’re looking for.

reviewText: Oxenfree is one of those games that takes a genre of game in terms of play and art style and flips it on its head. The use of radio as a plot device as well as a gameplay mechanic leads for some extremely creepy moments and my fondest expierences of this game so far have been when you know you need to tune the radio and something scary will happen, but you just don't want to and you're left sitting there freaking out. Strongly recommend to anyone who enjoys character driven narrative and extremely creepy horror aspects.

reviewText:
I really have no idea how to preface this review, so lets just get right into it's pros and cons.

Pros:
-5-8 hour playthrough length on average
-Gripping story
-Multiple endings make replaying the game a possibility
-Interesting bond between game mechanics and story progression
-(mostly) likable and relatable characters
-quality voice acting
-Charming art style
-Creepy horror elements
Cons:
-Slow walking makes travel tedious
-Replayability, however possible, might seem unneeded at first
-way too many damn kids with their beanies

Overall, A+/13
Would recommend to anyone looking for a gripping story and charming characters.

reviewText:
After finishing the game in one go, let me tell you how it is while its entirety is still fresh in my mind.

Here we go.

This game is best for fans of:
-Visual Novels
-Character Development
-Personalized Dialogue Between Characters
-People who care more about the characters than the plot
-Beautiful Atmospheric Indie Games
-The X-files
-Multiple Endings (though you can't track what you get really)

This game is not for:
-Hack and Slashers/Fast Paced Gamers
-People who like to 'get to the point'
-People who don't pay attention to the small things
-People who dislike teenagers, teenage jargon, teenage angst, and whiny teen problems
-Fans of walking speeds

Ways it can be improved:
-FASTER WALKING
-CHARACTER FRIENDSHIP STATS PAGE
-'I've already chose this option' indicator
-Save files
-Unlocked Endings List
-Animals in the environment (really though)
-Additional conversations when you've been walking around aimlessly
-Badges (yay!)

Now to more personal opinions:

Characters (A+):
Loved them. All of them. In their own teenage angsty way. Written well, voiced perfectly, and entirely believable. The depth of the characters go as far as you're willing to take it, and I appreciate that. Though, to get the full teenage experience, you have no idea what each character really thinks of Alex (the protagonist), but you can kind of figure it out. It would be nice if there was a 'friendship stats' bar. I was very surprised to see a certain character basically break off being friends with me in the final leg of the game. We hugged it out though.

Plot (C):
If you read the plot, I would say the game takes about seven or eight hours to complete. It's your X-Files type of plot, and though not soundly explained, it's interesting enough. Some parts of the plot were optional, though names were coming up that I know were in some papers I picked up....but were not memorable at all. (I'm hoping options where I could answer with 'Bob the sailor' means I picked up a 'Bob the sailor' tidbit earlier in the game) When I replay, I will be looking at the characters rather than the plot, really. What annoyed me the most was in order to complete the mini objectives, I would have had to circle around the map again at a very slow place, with no extra dialogue at all. Just quiet music and retracing footsteps....no thanks for now.

Atmosphere (B):
Visually stunning. Interesting Music. Movement speed is a literal D-R-A-G.
I would go on further about my likes and dislikes, but I'm not the best at critiquing these things with a keen eye.
The music was a bit repetitive, sometimes matching the mood, but let me feeling a bit empty.
The backgrounds and details were made with an amazing palette of matching colors that fit to the mood of the game. I'm only distressed that on this island, there were absolutely no animals except for a mysterious group of birds. A deer would have been nice to add to the forest ambiance, but when they said the island is deserted at, I guess the animals head back to the mainland too.

Extra:
-I enjoyed the radio system. I feel as if there's some secret station that places dubstep, but I have not found that yet and hope it exists. I'm sure there are easter eggs somewhere.
-The way the epilogue was done was nice.

Overall, the game is nice and worth the $20.

reviewText:
Overall, just a genuinely great game. Of course there were some things that could've been improved, but the characters were amazing, mainly in the sense that for once a game has actual realistic teenagers that aren't walking clichés.

The only really issues I had were that there was no way to see what the controls were, although this was only really an issue at the very start, but still I feel like it would've come in handy, and secondly, movement was a bit dodgy, both in the sense of the speed being very slow and also its a bit awkward when turning corners, although I eventually got over both of those problems.

The story was really good and I enjoyed the fact that there are multiple different endings and all that, although I wish you could see there was a way to rewind like in other choice based games instead of having to start over again.

Overall I'd probably give the game a 9/10 due to it being a really good game, definitely would recommend it. Great start to gaming in 2016.

reviewText:
I don't even know how to put my love for this game into words.

Oxenfree is the best game I've ever played, which is surprising considering I've only completed it once and played it less than fallout 4.

This game heavily focuses on character development in a good way. All the characters were believable in their intentions and way of speaking. The voice acting is top-notch, which only helps the immersion.
I recommend finishing the game in one session for the maximum effect.

Now, to the puzzles.
You solve different puzzles to save your friends after they've been possesed by some  ghost spirits 'living' on the island you're on. You do this using your handy pocket radio, which can also be used to tune into hidden frequencies such as a morse-code station, and your persuasive talking ability.  I really like this way of solving puzzles, the radio is a solid element in the game and speaking to other character is joyous. Again, the voice acting plays a large role in this.
All the puzzles that I encountered in my playthrough were fun to solve.

You can't quicksave before making a decision. Everything you can do is decide in the short timeframe given during dialogue. If you miss this chance, your character says nothing, which has an effect. (Huge props to nightschoolers for doing this)
While I did miss a decision I wanted to make because of this way of speaking, it worked perfectly every other time.

The supernatural elements in this game are very well done and can mess with your head some of the time, like they should. I actually almost broke my mouse when I got scared because I actually jumped in my chair. The only game to ever have done this is an indie game, isn't that funny?

I actually cried during the ending, which surprises me even today considering im a heartless monster in every other occasion.

TL;DR This game is amazing and you should definitely get it. Even if you hate teenagers, you'll like the characters in this game. Well, except one, but that one's intentional.

reviewText: Most story-driven games bounce off me pretty quickly because, frankly, I'm a real snob when it comes to games leaning heavily on stories.  Seriously, don't get me started.  Just don't.  I've been known to clear out entire rooms at parties.  But this game hooked me from the very first scene.  What really elevates Oxenfree is how the conversation system isn't the usual stilted dialogue menu: you talk, they talk, you talk, they talk, rinse, repeat.  It's amazing how well Oxenfree captures the natural pacing and flow of a conversation with great actors and smart dialog.  The intriguing setting and eerie story are just gravy.

reviewText:
Oxenfree is the first game that made me want to write a review for. Whether it will be your cup of tea or not, it’s an experience worth experiencing, and it is a rich experience. The narrative is as much a coming of age story as a supernatural thriller.

I am NOT a fan of Teenage drama, but the characters felt diverse and their actions believable given the circumstance they are put into that I was fully immersed. I know some people have criticised the stoic or jilted dialogue but I think they might have forgotten how teenagers talk, and how awkward they sound, however that stays true to their age as they are still discovering their voice, and much of their speech is emulated from what they emulate from the media, or what is expected of them from their peers, including clichés.

Another concern by fellow players is the long time that it takes to traverse the map, I didn’t find this much of a problem. There is constant dialogue between the characters, and dialogue options, as you walk. While there are long stretches of silence if you walk off the beaten path, for example to search for collectibles, I felt that I was actually still in character, examining her thoughts and how she is coming to terms with what is happening, how a normal person would like taking long night strolls on the beach to contemplate on their life. The characters grow throughout this experience! I only wish my real life walks had as amazing a soundtrack to go along with.

I finished the game with in my opinion the best ending possible and re watching the trailer of the game on the store page, I realise I did not see many of the events or dialogue portrayed and thus experience the different outcomes. As such, I can expect myself returning to this game in the future, although I admit I might find the long walks tedious then.

Side note, as someone who suffers from motion sickness, I appreciate the side scrolling view of Oxenfree and wish more horror games with rich stories can move out of the first person medium, as Oxenfree proved that isn’t required for immersion. I know this is a personal thing, but I play games for the story, I’m not ashamed to say my difficulty in games is always set to Easy, and I appreciate the fact that Oxenfree allows me to just get along with the juicy plot without having to dodge necromorphs or rationing ammo while constantly worry about jumpscares. I don’t lie awake at night thinking of monsters, but I do from the thought of how small we are in the universe, what happens when we die etc. That is true Horror, me thinks.

Finally, to those who complain that their $20 ($28AUD) should have bought them more game time etc (I finished the game in about 5 hours), I think you really have to think about the quality over the quantity here, this is a game that remains in my mind, the soundtrack of the game could be worth this much alone, or even the background illustration of each ‘level’. There are few things in life, much less games I pay for that my wallet doesn’t hurt after from a serious case of buyer’s remorse, but Oxenfree isn’t one of them. I think it’s priced just right as any higher would’ve scared me away from trying it , but now that I have, I would gladly pay more.

reviewText:
Oxenfree is a mellow and engaging dialogue-driven adventure game with an 80's teen sci-fi horror vibe.

The story is engaging and the characters feel natural, your choices are often varied and feel like they matter in the form of how relationships are formed and managed. Whilst (usually) not life-or-death decisions, your choice of who to support, who to challenge, and who to work with feel very honest and natural. This helps the game feel grounded and gives the characters a believability, which helps you invest in them as things start to fall apart around you.

If I could criticise anything about the game, I'd say it doesn't play it's cards close enough to it's chest, from just a few minutes into the game some strangely sci-fi things are happening and we learn a lot about what's wrong on the island fairly early on. To the game's credit, this didn't diminish my desire to continue hunting for even more clues, and the drama kept me hooked right until the games closing credits, but a little more mystery and build up early on would have been nice.

Overall, I absolutely loved this game, and I'm eagerly looking forward to whatever Night School Studio turn their hand to next. I recommend this game, thoroughly, and whole-heartedly.

reviewText: It didn’t immediately grip me, but once the story picked up I was completely hooked. Oxenfree does eerie very well. It’s wonderfully atmospheric too, brought to life by its excellent sound design, music, and beautiful art. Alex and Jonas were fantastic protagonists, and I loved their banter so much it may have been my favorite part of the game. I just wish they walked a little bit faster though...\n\nIf you’re a fan of things like The Twilight Zone, The Outer Limits, or the X-Files, and don’t mind a little teen drama tossed into the mix, definitely check this out. In the end, it's a beautiful and haunting character story, and I enjoyed it greatly.

reviewText:
I really liked this game :) and I wanted to like it more. But something of it felt a bit off which stopped me from loving it unlike with Transistor for example. After playing Life is Strange loads of times too, I guess some games can't bring the same excitement or feels.

Oxenfree is a pretty awesome game with a neat artistic style of the backgrounds. I wasn't sure at first what to think of it when I started playing. But eventually it become really enjoyable.
It tells a nice story about Alex, who goes to an island with a group of friends. But you will find out that it's not just any normal trip as something strange happens which involves nasty ghosts. The game is rather small in size and you mostly move left or right.

It has a rich amount of dialogues between characters. The voice acting is really good and the characters speak quite fast sometimes, so there is a chance you might miss something they say. Oxenfree has a lot of choice making during conversations and the difference between this and for example Life is Strange, is that you don't have much time to think.
You have to make your choices rather quickly every time, which I didn't like so much. The island has an eerie/spooky feeling, which fits well with the setting. The music, well it's just great ^_^. Not the best I have heard, but it slightly reminds me of some 80's movie or tv-show and few of the songs really stood out. The game reminded me how creepy radios can be, just like with Silent Hill :P.

The story had some good moments imo, it tries to be different which is never a bad thing and ending of the game was great. I will not spoil anything though.

Hmm anyway, I recommend people to play this but with the current price it can feel expensive to some, as the game isn't very long. Unless you collect stuff etc. So it might be better to wait for a slight price drop. It took me about 6 hours to finish Oxenfree, but stats show more although I wasn't exactly playing all the time. Great game overall to add into 2016 games list :).

reviewText: Another great game to start off the new year, Oxenfree is a narrative focused adventure game made by ex-Telltale devs. Oxenfree is a very pretty and atmospheric game with a nice soundtrack. Its writing is also quality stuff and the voice acting really sells it both making for a likable cast that sound pretty natural. The flow of the dialogue is also unique because you have to make your choices on the fly and you can walk around while doing it. The core of the gameplay is your interactions with Alex’s friends and new step-brother while you explore the island using your radio to uncover the island’s past. My only real complaints are that sometimes the game doesn’t give you enough time to respond, like only a scant few seconds, also the ending twist doesn't really fit thematically well if you play a certain way and just feels like a cheap gotcha twist. Otherwise it’s really good and a must play for adventure game fans. I’m looking forward to whatever Night School makes next because this was quite the strong first game.

reviewText:

Graphics and overall feel is really lovely - the music and sound effects are also well suited to the atmosphere of the game as a whole. Voice acting was GREAT! Loved the radio and how it got tied in during the game.

Excellent story; very engaging. Collectibles are definitely a challenge.

Varying endings are pretty cool as well. Can't fault it for choices and subtlety in story points and nice touches here and there.

Only complaint is that it's terribly slow to play, purely because of the walking places and Alex having a set gait most of the time. She can run, but it's still pretty slow getting around as the player cannot control that. reviewText:
PROS:

- The game has a beautiful art style.
- The walking and talking doesn't feel as awkward of clunky" as the trailer had me believe it would be
date:
everything "flows" nicely.
- The music is lovely and really works with each environment I've visited so far.
- The choices you make in conversations are interesting.
- The dialogue feels real and the characters are actually fleshed out and interesting to interact with.
- The voice acting is the winner here. It's just superb. Zero complaints. Really makes the game!

CONS:

I'd recommend this to adventure/story rich-friendly gamers who don't mind a lot of talking to sit through and are looking for something new to try out!

reviewText:
I usually just write short one or two line reviews for games, but I think Oxenfree deserves so much more. It's an amazingly crafted adventure game with some of the best voice acting I've ever seen in a game like this. The fact that it's an indie game honestly surprises me. It's got some scary moments (I'm not done with the game, only about 3 hours into my first playthrough, and I intend at least one or two more), but mostly it's just beautifully scripted, and flows so well, that you can honestly get through the huge amount of really very satisfying dialogue while you're doing the exploring and stuff. I am slightly annoyed by the fact that dialogue doesn't carry from one area to the next, so if you want to hear all of a conversation you gotta stand around and wait just a little bit, but I honestly think it's worth it.

Take it from someone who usually plays JRPGs, action RPGs, and dungeon crawlers on an almost religious basis, Oxenfree is an adventure game for basically anyone ever, especially if you like creepy ♥♥♥♥.

Also the radio tuning mechanic is cool as hell.

reviewText: Back to the past, when we were younger and better, when you met new people on a trip, when you only wanted to drink that saturday night, when explore a cave was a mystery to solve, and a little noise was Satan himself speaking to you, when partying could turn into an adventure... all those feelings, are here. Oxenfree is a minimalist game. An incredible walking simulator story-driven adventure full of emotion. You will want to discover its history, you will want to resolve its mistery. It's beatiful, it's sad, it's evocative. It has an amazing soundtrack, and a great art design. And probably the best conversation system I've seen in this type of game, intuitive, nice and simple. An adventure, with friends and a mistery to solve. One of those kind of unique games.

reviewText:
Date reviewed: 17/01/2016
Genre: Adventure/2D point & click/TellTale-like

Summary: After playing almost 5 hours straight of Oxenfree, I was very impressed with the game and was left wanting more. This game reminds me a lot of Life is Strange, with supernatural elements to keep it fresh and different. A very strong debut title from Night School Studio and perhaps the first best game of 2016.

Positive aspects of this game:

+ Plot - to say anything would give away the main story. However, I found it realistic, engaging and I felt invested in my characters to survive.

+ Characters - this is perhaps the strongest aspect of the game, and like plot, cannot really be spoken about without giving anything away. Each character has their own personality, their own flaws, and their own desires. The beginning of the story gives you an idea of what each character might be like, but as with any good narrative, there is more to each character than you might first believe.

Similarly built of that is the dialogue system - your dialogue options (similar to TellTale's dialogue system), is greatly influenced by each of your relationships with each of the different characters. I was very impressed with this, and had a lot of fun poking fun/insulting different characters ;)

+ The Environments - I really enjoyed the different environments created, and the art aesthetic for each respectively. For instance, in the abandoned school it felt very creepy and sinister. And each environment feels very different from the last one (although continuous), keeping the feeling of immersion in this world.

+ Voice Acting - I was not familar with voice actors listed on the steam product page, but it didn't matter because all voice acting is very strong. Ren is well voiced as the typical stoner, Clarissa as the evil girl, Nona as the shy, bookworm, Alex (you) as the main protagonist and Jonas as your unknown step-brother.

+ Gameplay - fairly simple, most of the gameplay revolves around discovery of the supernatural elements on the island and your interactions with each character, utilizing the dialogue system as previously mentioned. I was very impressed as the game quizzes your ability to explore and understand the island around you, something that I think is missed in many games.

Similarly, throughout the game, you will constantly use a radio-tuning mechanic to solve puzzles. I felt this was appropriate to the context and enjoyed it a lot.

+ Music - I had no problems with the background score. Never felt irritating during the 4.7 hours. I'll be honest, most of the time, I didn't notice it as I was too busy focused on the character dialogue.

Negatives

- At first when I loaded the game, I could barely play the game with incredibly poor framerates (for a 2D game!). This apparently is an issue for some graphics cards. The developer is apparently aware of this, and posted a solution, but I felt that this shouldn't have been an issue. I hope a future patch will fix this by the developer.

My score 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Whoa. Okay.

So even from last year when the game was announced, I was already hyped for it. And I'm happy to say that the final product did not disappoint. This game has such a unique and beautiful art style that I've never seen before, coupled with a minimalistic interface and absolutely SUPERB writing and voice acting. I loved the seamless flow of dialogue between the characters, I was very intrigued by the story and the horror elements. The ending to me at first felt a little...abrupt, but I was left quite thrilled at the plot twist which, even though I saw coming, was still pretty darn cool.

My only gripes were that there were still a few glitches in the game I noticed, where the characters that accompanied me got stuck in some places, which was slightly immersion-breaking. But it's totally understandable since the game literally just dropped. Another little nitpick is I wish there was a fast-travel system for the island, especially in the later stages. Since I'm a completionist, I wanted to explore and find the collectibles, but it was a bit tedious having to manually go everywhere. A fast travel system from point to point would have been handy.

If you're a fan of story-driven, choice-based games like TellTale games or Life is Strange, then this game is without question meant for you. I really enjoyed it and will probably play through it several more times, just to see the different outcomes. And honestly, the story makes it make SENSE to play through the game more than once. If you've finished it, you'll understand why.

UPDATE (June 2, 2016): There's now a New Game + mode available for this game, and I just finished it. Personally I found it to be a bit underwhelming, since the description promised a lot more than what the game gave, I thought. It had a very interesting new ending, and several new additions that kept me somewhat engaged, but for the most part there really wasn't THAT much added. If you're like me and have previously played at least 5-6 playthroughs of the game already, you'd spend most of it trying to seek out as much new content as possible, and I guess I was disappointed that there wasn't enough of it in my opinion. I was expecting some sort of big expansion or a ton more new dialogue options/scenarios. Still, it was something new.

reviewText:
DESPITE BEING SPOILER FREE, FOR THE BEST EXPERIENCE DO NOT CONTINUE READING. GO PLAY THE GAME.
This review contains no spoilers. But going in blind will lead to the most thorough enjoyment.




Oxenfree is a throwback to 80s teen horror flicks that starts out in a way that will have you raising a doubtful eyebrow.


The dialogue is this game's primary appeal, and it's what will immerse you the most. In fact I don't think there's another game out there like it. Nothing even comes close to how well it flows. It doesn't sound like everyone recorded their lines separately. There's no delayed interruptions, there's no lines that sound like they were delivered at gun point, or recorded by someone pulled off the street; and during conversations, you have to choose what to say quickly or your time will run out. Conversations carry on, with or without you. You can interrupt people, and they'll cut off in a way that seems real. You could spend the whole game without saying a thing (if you want to be perceived as creepier than anything that happens on the island). There exist games out there where certain characters have better voice acting, however as an entire package, it's exemplary. It has wonderful, realistically delivered and flowing lines and despite being made by a small indie team, big names like Bioware, Naughty Dog, CD Projekt and more recently Don't Nod should absolutely take note.

There is no gameplay besides walking, talking, and the game's primary mechanic, the radio. Alex (you) can use it to tune in to anomalies, a few easter eggs, radio stations (that shouldn't exist) and even manipulate the environment. While it isn't what most people would describe as a horror game, as I said above, it's a throwback to 80s light hearted horror that would star an all teen cast, and there are more than a few places where you will be spooked, or you'll be a teensy bit on edge.

The story starts out light. There are multiple endings, all of which surprised me. Even the CREDITS had somethings very unexpected. An amazing, simple touch that connects everybody that plays the game.

This is a game that will absolutely stick with me. And it's something I'll recommend to anyone that's a fan of story driven games, mystery, the paranormal, or anything that revolves heavily around the characters and less on the gameplay. If you liked Life is Strange, Firewatch, the Stanley Parable etc, you will like this game.

reviewText:
Olly olly oxenfree! This game is worth the cost. I've played the game a couple times now, and I strongly suggest that others should play Oxenfree. I will go ahead & say that this game is not meant for people who do not have patience.

PROS:
+ Intriguing story & ending, wonderful in-depth characters, and great dialogue w/ the protagonist.
+ Have to be somewhat quick to select a text bubble, making the atmosphere feel more honest in convos.
+ Choices do matter & leave an impact. It can determine whether people live/die & the relationships you form.
+ Dialogue adds to the feel of just a couple teenagers trying to make it through the night on a mysterious island.
+ Art & scenery is beautiful & amazing.

CONS:
- Minor bugs where characters would get stuck.
- Dialogue would occasionally get skipped if I accidentally triggered something too soon.
- Can be slow when traveling across the map, but at least they have little things for the player to find.

To get the fullest experience of this game, I'd advise you to take your time & be patient. This game is meant to be explored. I enjoyed this game despite the major plot twist at the end that nearly had me screaming.

reviewText: This is the first game where I've felt motivated to write a Steam review.  At first I thought Oh!  It's just an adventure game where you walk around and talk and reveal a story.  Even though that's the meat of the game, the writing and voice acting do add a lot and the way conversation feels like it flows naturally (with you as a participant) is unique in my experience.  There's also a lot of haunting music and glitchy effects which create a great creepy atmosphere.  I don't think I was scared much playing this game but I was definitely unsettled.  Enjoyably unsettled, if that's a thing.\n\nYou do make meaningful choices which eventually affect the ending.  I've only played through once so far but it's a short enough game (and the characters are fleshed out enough) that I am eager to play through again and make different conversational choices to see what happens.  I hadn't heard much of anything about this game before I picked it up on sale but it's a novel experience that stuck with me and I hope more people try it.  I've seen other people describe it as slow and that's a fair knock, but I'm keen to see what these developers do next.

reviewText:
Oxenfree. I never heard of this game until a few days ago thanks to a Let's Player named Bowlingotter who played 2 hours on a live stream. After seeing that, I began to debate getting it for the $19.99 full price, but something about it drew me to it.

I can say it is money well spent.

What is this game? It's sort of a point and click adventure, with mysteries and spookiness abounding. You play as Alex, a young teenage woman going to an island with some friends, and your new step-brother. As the game progresses you find out the darker secrets of the island, but you also build relationships with your friends, and depending on how you play and how you treat them will determine different things later on, including the various endings you can receive.

How is the gameplay? It's very good. There's a mechanic involving a radio and finding hidden radio stations that is good for those who like to know more about the mystery and also like collectables + achievements. It's all very simple and works very well.

I also would like to praise the voice acting in this game. I was instantly reminded of Life is Strange, another favorite, with the dialogue and level of voice acting here. Everyone does a great job, and there's a LOT of talking, but I never was bored or thought the dialouge was corny; In fact, I wanted more of it. Major kudos to the studio and actors for pulling this off - it could have gone the other way, and never did.

The game also presents the player with various choices much like Telltale games, Until Dawn, or, again, Life is Strange. You get three choices, normally, and this will lead to various responses depending on what you said, and this also allows for a lot of replayability.

The game does, as the description says, revolve around ghosts and it is quite spooky and eerie in parts, specifically relating to the radio, but there's no gore or anything, just spooks and mystery.

I got all the collectables and had a wonderful time. I don't normally spring for a full priced game, especially one I just heard of and is a new IP, but if you're on the fence, I'd say give it a go. If you liked any of the other games I mentioned, I think you'll like this game. It took me about 8 hours, but it's 8 hours of really good and fun content, and some $60 games have that much content, but isn't as good or deep.

As I said, I didn't hear of this game til recently, but I'm so glad I did, and I will be replaying it for sure, not just for the achievements, but the experience, the interaction of characters (which I ended up liking!) and just enjoying the game as a whole, and you should too!

reviewText:
Short version: the less you know about the game, the more it can surprise and delight you. If you like adventure games, please just go play it now, it's really superb.

Longer version: What a beautiful little gem of an adventure game.

Wonderfully written and voiceacted characters you completely fall in love with and care about. Tons of wonderful, fun dialogue that's just a joy to listen and react to. You feel compelled to explore the environments just a bit more just to see if visiting some place elicits a little more conversations from the cast.

Genuinely funny, heartfelt and engaging human relationships, drama and uncertainties mixes with a thrilling supernatural mystery you're just dying to find out more of. I've only played through once so far, but it's evident what you do and say during the game can change things and the way people feel about you in several surprising ways, so I feel especially compelled to go back and play differently, not only to see what different endings there are, but also to hear all the conversations and little stories I missed.

I am in love with this game, and if you get emotionally invested in adventure stories and mysteries and likeable characters, you will probably fall in love too. It's wonderful. Just don't spoil it for yourself.

9/10

reviewText: I usually don't write reviews but I have to for this game because it completely captured my attention for hours, leaving me excited to finish it in one go just to see how the story played out. The characters are natural, flowing, and completely fleshed out - most teenage characters are based off of archetypes and left there, but these characters feel real and play off of each other well. The dialog is lighthearted, and the choices to respond have variation and characters remember what you say, giving it a high replay value.\nThe story is beautiful and sad all in one, the landscape is lovingly crafted and not too expansive (as the walking can be a little repetitive), and the hidden clues are in depth and well scattered throughout the island. I love this game and wish for it to gain in popularity as I would love to see more content. It's original, the soundtrack adds a wonderful ambience that would have left something missing otherwise, and it remains an entirely different experience from most games I have played.\n(Where Life is Strange does hold similar concepts: time bending, teenagers, horror, choice led, fate vs free will; Oxenfree stands as an entirely different experience with much to prove.)

reviewText:
After my first playthrough and spending 4 hours with Oxenfree I'm left with mixed emotions.

On one hand, the way Oxenfree tells it's story while moving adds a sense of flow to the game that is rarely seen in narrative heavy adventures. The art style pops, the dialogue has a solid mix of believabilty and humour, and the narrative setting really works. As the story progressed, my want to be head over heels for this game was tested by a story that bounces around with it's pacing and some narratively muddled closing points.

I'd reccomend Oxenfree to anyone interested, and would hold back some of my negative faults to let them come to their own conclusions. I feel this way simply because the merits that Oxenfree does have are so strong, even if it doesn't fully hit it out of the park.

reviewText: Oxenfree is a dialogue-heavy adventure game about a group of teenagers who go on a trip to a mysterious island, only to have their night of drinking quickly turn into a thrilling story of the supernatural.  Much of the game is spent wandering around figuring out what to do next, while engaging in interactive conversations among the group of friends.  When it is the main character's turn to speak, you are presented with up to 3 dialogue options - and if you don't choose any before the speech bubbles fade away, the character will say nothing.  One of the game's biggest strengths is that many of these dialogue choices actually do have an impact on the game's story - they can affect anything from the characters' friendship levels to significant changes in the ending.  Although the ending comes rather abruptly, it is interesting to see the many different ways that it can vary, thus giving the game a fair amount of replay value.  Also adding to the game's replay value are hidden collectibles that explain more of the backstory.  That being said, it would have been convenient if the developers had added a running option - your character can only walk, which can add some monotony to finding these collectibles.  On the bright side, the considerable amount of dialogue between the characters will tend to break this monotony when following the main path.\n\nThe graphical style in this game consists of 3D character models on top of beautifully-drawn 2D backgrounds, all of which blend together smoothly.  However, I did notice some lag as I was walking through certain areas - and I have a powerful computer that can play far more demanding games than this without a problem.  Nonetheless, it is clear the developers poured tons of effort into polishing their game, and this can especially be seen in the voice acting.  You will feel as though you are listening to a real group of teenagers, and their reactions are very believable in any different situation they are placed in, no matter which dialogue options you choose.  The soundtrack, while not particularly memorable, fits the game's atmosphere very well.  The consensus review score for Oxenfree seems to be around 8/10, and I find this to be a fair rating.  $20 is a bit steep, though, so it's probably best to buy it on sale.

reviewText:
Whereas most of these narrative games are content to give the player only trivial cosmetic decisions, with little or no bearing on the story's outcome, Oxenfree provides genuine player choice. That probably shouldnt be remarkable in itself given that there's an established genre of choice-based games, but it is. For that alone it deserves praise.

Just the way in which its choices and branching storyline work is superior to most. Rather than railroading you from point to point where you're called upon to make big, sweeping, clearly telegraphed decisions (which are probably illusory), in Oxenfree far more of the player's input is taken into account. Unlike in Life is Strange or Telltale games where your conversations only really matter at specific points and everything else is filler, in Oxenfree your actions and words throughout build or deteoriate your relationship with other characters, and even have a knock on effect wherein something you've influenced another character to do will change another character's opinion of them - this shows that the game's world doesnt solely revolve around you, and it adds a real sense of life to the cast as a whole.

I'll also say that while comparable supernatural game Life is Strange leans too heavily on its supernatural elements (to the detriment of its focus on what really matters, character development), Oxenfree never loses sight of the fact that its characters are its most important element, and that the extreme situation they're in serves primarily to draw out their personalities. As a result I became invested in them and stayed emotionally invested throughout.

As for its aesthetics, Life is Strange leaned heavily on it's lovely visuals and lighting to make up for a lack of genuine choice, but Oxenfree has both. Its music and painterly art-style are perfectly atmospheric - and in places genuinely beautiful - and its voice-acting is emotive and high quality. The radio you carry with you - which some reviewers have criticised for the weak puzzle mechanics relating to it - is a better tool for building atmosphere than gameplay. Throughout the game you can tune to various stations, and listen to them gradually become more distorted and bizzare as the night goes on.

I do however have various complaints about the game. Firstly the game is heavily linear, and though its branching map appears at first glance to encourage taking different routes to objectives, and searching for collectibles, the fact that characters fall dead silent when you're not on the prescribed narrative route sucks the life from these activities. An inability to control walking speed also makes finding these collectibles in obscure corners of the map laborious. I can quite understand why they did that - having players dash through the map would break pacing - but at the same time having just a little more control over speed would have been nice.

Secondly there's the fact that the conversation system is not perfect. Too often picking a dialogue choice will simply cut through whatever anyone else was saying, and while the system seems fairly intelligent in getting characters to pick interrupted subjects back up, you can never know whether or not there are things you missed entirely (at least not without reloading your save to the last checkpoint, but that would break immersion). In some instances Alex will wait until a natural point in the conversation to speak your choice herself - but you can never tell when. Given the fast and fluid nature of the game's conversation system, in which your dialogue option bubbles fade away quickly, I often found myself seeing just how long I could wait before having to press one so that I wouldnt miss out on any more of another character's dialogue. Once or twice I missed my chance to say anything at all.

Thirdly you have the length. Now I stretched it over multiple sessions because I like to savour these things, but it would have been very possible to complete the whole game in a single sitting. In about four hours. Now you could spin this as a positive, say that it didnt overstay its welcome, say that it was just the right length it needed to be and didnt contain filler - and perhaps given the technical difficulties of making a choice game it really couldnt have been any longer. These things grow exponentially more complicated the longer they go on and the more branches devs have to take into account. But nonetheless, the fact remains that time and familiarity are a considerable part of emotional connection to a character, and with more time the game could have explored its cast with greater depth and subtlety.

Maybe these sound like heavy criticisms, but keeping in mind all the substantial positives I outlined at the beginning of this review, buy it. These complaints are nitpicks in comparison. Of course everything could be better, could be improved, but for what it is I strongly recommend Oxenfree to anyone who enjoys this style of game.

reviewText:
Oxenfree was a great game. There was some pretty noticable downsides to this game but ill get to that later. Also this is a spoiler free review.
So first, the positives.
Artwork and aesthetic of this game was beautiful. It was very pleasing on the eye. The overall design of the game was great. So was soundtrack. The overall atmosphere of the game is great.
The gameplay and story was also interesting. It felt new, as the radio mechanic is something i havent seen before. And i love how you can choose the path of the story, and have so many dialouge options. Basically it was a good game.
BUT the reason i wrote this review was because of the negitives.
Ill start off with the dialouge. Ill start off with saying, i hate inturrupting as well as being inturrupted. The dialouge in this game makes it so you either inturrupt the character speaking, or you wait until theyre done speaking (which will result in the dialouge options either almost faded away or just gone.) I found that really hard to get over. Another thing i found is if you are in the middle of an important dialouge sequence and you inspect something in the middle of it, you may become stuck. The dialouge doesnt go back to what they were saying before, so you basically need to replay the whole sequence.
Which brings me to another point: The save points.
I really beleive there should be a save point instead of just waiting to finish the sequence. The points where the game saves are pretty far away which was a pretty big inconvenience.
I also found the characters to be pretty unrealistic at times, as they would pick fights where fights shouldnt have been. And i think they could have approached that more realisticly, because i had a hard time beleiving that would ever happen in real life.
Basically, theres a lot of cons. But i really liked the game. It has GREAT replay value as theres so many different routes you can take it. I think the pros outweigh the cons, and if it intrests you, go for it and buy it. its a great experience.

TLDR; Game needs work, but that doesnt outweigh the fact that its a good game, and it doesnt mean you shouldnt buy it

reviewText:
Pros:
- Super pretty artwork.
- Prioritizes story progression over tricky gameplay that'll hold you up.
- Option to gather up collectibles or bypass and continue the story to move faster.
- Lots of little secrets hidden around that reveal further plot and deeper insight.
- Story alters depending on what responses you give as the player, making it feel more personalized.
- Despite the pretty, chill artwork, you will get chills from some of the scenes. It is a horror game!
- Story seems straightforward but actually has a lot of complexity and surprises involved. Reminiscent of an '80s horror film.
- Short and easily played through in one sitting. This makes it easy to replay for alternate endings.

Cons:
- Lots of typos in the letters, in the subtitles, and everywhere you look. This is a huge pet peeve of mine. If you're going to put so much effort into making the artwork beautiful, please bother to proofread the text as well. :(
- A little expensive for the length of the game.
- Movements are a little awkward. It's easy to get stuck on edges or cliffs and you're slow, which discourages exploration.
- There are some lingering bugs. At one point the NPC following me got stuck at the top of a hill and wouldn't jump down. I was waiting at a point where he needed to join me before the page would transition. It soft locked the game and I had to alt+F4 to retry it. He got stuck after the reset too, so I had to take a different route through the world to bypass the issue entirely.

reviewText:
This game isn't perfect but I'm so glad I played it.

Positives:
+ A game that understands how actual young people talk.
+ Likeable, nuanced characters.
+ Realistic & enjoyable relationship development throughout the game.
+Just good dialogue, in general.
+ Incredible skill at building suspense and an 'enemy' that's powerful and memorable. Some sequences around this have really stuck in my head.
+ Some unique mechanics that are really inventive and cool (the mirror thing, to those in the know).
+It's completely gorgeous. Backgrounds and character design are so pretty and memorable.
+While the choice aspect isn't outstanding, there are a few really clever options.

Negatives:
-To get all of the small points out of the way at once: the subtitles are often wrong (in small ways but it's noticeable and jarring), the narrow paths and slow walking speed can get annoying, the radio lock mechanic can be kind of a drag later on in the game, and the dialogue system has a unique look but in practice can be clunkier than something like Telltale's usual system.
-Trying to avoid spoilers as much as possible, I found some of the later plot points very unsatisfying. There seemed to be some unnecessary cutting off of branching story paths, especially since this isn't the kind of game where the story gets continued in a sequel.
-Character approval and its results can be confusing (I genuinely thought I was experiencing a glitch at one point), but this might be somewhat unique to my playthrough.
-Characters' reactions to things can seem kind of muted, particularly later in the game. On the other hand, it can get really irritating in thriller/horror games to hear the characters generically freaking out throughout the whole thing, so it's understandable why the writers would want to avoid too much of this.

This could either be a positive or a negative depending on your perspective, but playing through once leaves some things unclear and unexplained.

It's better at atmosphere and dialogue than choice mechanics and branching paths in my opinion, so it might be best to go into it with that it mind. I still strongly recommend it though. There are moments from this story that I'll remember for a long time.

reviewText:
Oxenfree is a quaint horror/thriller adventure driven by dialogue selection and tuning into radio frequencies.

The premise of the game is that you play as Alex, a girl who is on an island at night with some of her high school friends/acquaintences where they plan on just hanging out and getting drunk until some cave exploring goes wrong and unleashes a supernatural force upon them.

Oxenfree is definitely an odd one, it has similarities to other games in terms of the overall feel, but it really does stand out as rather unique. For this game to be succesful. the story would have to work as at it's heart, the game is story driven. The core game mechanic is actually your choice of dialogue. When other people are conversing, you get transient dialogue options, which you have a few selections to pick what you wish to say. You can also opt to remain silent, which in of itself can also be a game driving choice. Either way, the choices you make with regards to the dialogue influence the outcome of the game and how it progresses. I especially liked how you only have a limited amount of time to make your choice, as I feel this in of itself can drive your decision making. In most games, NPC's will just sorta wait around for as long as you like until you make your decision, but in Oxenfree there is a sense of urgency in saying what you want to say. So despite almost being visual novel-esque in game/story progression, there is some quick thinking to be done, and if you really want to catch all the dialogue you do need to be on the ball.

I enjoyed the story, it was certainly different to any game I've played before. There's plenty of teen high school drama, which serves its purpose and the voice acting is very good. The cast of characters are well fleshed out, and I felt that there was enough done for me to care about the various characters and appreciate their motivations.  I definitely got some 'Life is Strange' vibes from the way the characters were written, which I'd say is a good thing. This really is integral to how the game plays out as the choices you make in game also affect the outcomes for the other characters.

The scenery artwork for Oxenfree is gorgeous. I love the watercolour style backdrops, the island is fun to explore. The atmosphere is great, for the various regions of the island. The sounds also help this. Ambience is used well to set the tone of the area you're in. Navigation relies on you walking around the island, and I guess it's laid out like a platformer so it looks 2D, but you can walk in 3 dimensions so I guess it's a visually 2D game with 3D function. Whatever it is, it works.

As a horror game - it's definintely not one of the scarier games I've played. It certainly uses elements of horror, but I'm not sure how far I'd define it as a full on horror game. It dabbles in sci-fi/the supernatural in it's own way, but I'm not sure I'd really call it a sci fi game either. I guess genre isn't too important here as it's all pretty fluid. I think it succeeds in building a sense of uneasiness in the key parts where it needs to. The use of lighting, music and sounds really helps this.

In terms of controls, I played this with an xbox one controller and it played perfectly (supports rumble function too, which is a nice touch for sure). It's not a game of precision, a controller is perhaps the most comfortable way to play this, though I'd imagine keyboard works fine too.

Overall, the game is quite short (I finished it in under 5 hours) but I feel this is fine, particularly given the pacing of the game and how you drive it forward. I think for what it is, the length is fine and it does a lot with that time in order to tell a compelling story. I enjoyed the gameplay, was invested in the story and would be interested to see if the devs are putting out any similar titles any time soon. It didn't blow me away but it was a unique, enjoyable experience and I'd give this a solid recommendation.

reviewText:
Oxenfree Review

https://youtu.be/pGPYijRLN9k

Not a sequel to Olli Olli

• Platforms: Xbox One, PC (Reviewed)
• Publisher: Night School Studio
• Developer: Night School Studio
------

There is no skateboarding in Oxenfree, nor is there any awesome music to listen to while you try your best to string together various combos that would make Tony Hawk blush.
Oxenfree is, however, extremely interesting despite these obvious shortcomings.

------Story------

In the game, you play as Alex, a young girl on her way to a party with her friends on the mysterious Edward's Island. After exploring one of the island's caves, you and your friends stumble upon an anomaly that turns the night into a fight for survival. And that's really all I can say without ruining the plot and its various twists.

The story is compelling, and explores some very interesting themes. It's also a very human story; something I don't think can be praised enough. So many games that release nowadays always feature generic, cynical archetypes that are ultimately forgettable (think Harkin from Lords of the Fallen, or Aiden Pierce from Watch_Dogs). The characters in Oxenfree feel like real people, even if some of them might be completely insufferable...

Aside from a few extremely obnoxious characters, the dialogue is very well written. And you can tell the writers are aware of this because their characters never shut up. These people blather on so much, I thought the game glitched during a segment where the characters were silent for about 5 minutes. It can get really tiresome listening to these kids go on and on about every single thought that pops into their head, especially considering (as far as I could tell) there was no way to skip dialogue. Perhaps all of this would have been more tolerable if there were a skateboarding section... oh well.

------Gameplay------

For all intents and purposes, Oxenfree is a point-and-click adventure game with multiple endings. However, there are several mechanics that keep the game from feeling too formulaic. Alex's radio can tune into various frequencies on the island, unlocking secrets, hidden anomalies, and even areas. It's also connected to the game's narrative.

You will also be given free rein of Edward's Island. Unlike most of its contemporaries, Oxenfree offers players a metroidvania-style world to explore as they see fit. This is both a positive and a negative, though, as Alex walks like she has nowhere to be. She also occasionally struggles to navigate the environments, which can be frustrating. This is obviously done intentionally to make sure you hear all of the characters' unimportant dialogue, but it feels excruciating to realize you've gone to the wrong area, only to have to crawl back to where you were supposed to go at a snail's pace. Thankfully, backtracking never feels like much of an issue, as the developers saw fit to keep previously explored areas interesting by adding to them upon returning.

One odd (likely intentional) choice from the developer was to severely limit the amount of time you have to pick your dialogue option. It didn't occur often enough that I felt it was interfering with how I wanted the narrative to unfold, but it was certainly noticeable. At certain points I was forced to randomly click something before I had time to read all the options available to me. This is usually done to create tension, but it can create frustration if not done correctly. I still can't help but feel all of these minor gripes could have been avoided if only there were more skateboarding sections.

------Presentation------

Oxenfree is beautiful. From the very mellow soundtrack, to the wonderful hand-painted environments, this is s game that is pleasant to the senses. The voice work is also top-notch; all the actors and actresses do a phenomenal job.

Aside from that, I did notice a few glitches. As I mentioned earlier, Alex will occasionally struggle with the very narrow pathways of Edwards Island. I also experienced one glitch where a character wasn't performing an action needed to advance the game, forcing me to restart.

Still, there were no crashes, and the game ran fine on my fairly standard PC. Could have used more skateboarding, though.

------Arbitrary Score------

Oxenfree is a good game, though not one without its flaws. It's certainly worth the asking price of $19.99, and if you ever see the game on sale, be sure to jump on it.

8/10

reviewText:
Simply one of the best narrative driven adventure games to date. My final video review is still in the works, but I don't want to delay this recommendation -- play Oxenfree. It is visually gorgeous, along with containing an absolutely fantastic sound scape of music and stellar sound design. It's writing is damn impressively well done and even puts some of Telltale's work to shame. The variety of choices, both big and small, is fantastic (even if there is a limit as far as different endings, due to the game's four hour length). Even the radio gameplay mechanic is surprisingly engaging.

My only real complaint is that the game's refusal to let you have manual control over your walking speed makes backtracking for collectibles a genuine chore. But those are really only there for three achievements and for some extra backstory, so it's not a huge loss if you ignore them or collect them all.

While I will agree that $20 seems a bit much for a game that can be beaten in four hours, considering I am already planning to play through at least two more times, the cost evens out, and you can also elect to get the game on sale (I waited until it hit $15).

Overall, it is a solid piece of work, and I look forward to what Night School has planned for their next title. Buy it, play it, and then play it again.

reviewText:
This was one of the VERY few games that I was super excited to play and followed it up to its release because of it's very unique gameplay and story. It's a walking simulator for the most part but unless you're drifting off the main path, you'll always have a conversation going that you can interact with by choosing dialogues want as you walk.

The first hour really hooked me and I honestly wasn't expecting it to have such an eerie and creepy (sometimes jumpscary) feel to it but damn, at times it really sent shivers down my spines. Though after that first hour it was more of just going through the game, interacting with objects, moving on the the next objective, etc. It felt super repetitive even though its never the same dialogue (to an extent). I have no idea how extensive the choices I make will impact the outcomes in the future until I play it for the second time. It definitely has 2 or 3 replayability, but only if you're willing to go through some of the same things again, I am but only after a couple of months. Overall, if you love games for its story and you love choose your own adventure games, this is an awesome catch!

Just one more thing, I went through the whole game and really thought I was being cool with everyone and trying to be on their nice side but I literally got the worst outcome possible. I don't even trust myself after that.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Great story-driven horror game. This brand of horror game doesn't depend on jump scares and monsters, however, instead throwing you into the story of a short trip gone wrong, where a group of high-school age friends end up opening a time/dimensional rift by accident while exploring some anomalies on an island.

The storyline draws heavily from 80s horror movies, yet it feels fresh enough that you get engrossed by it while it manages to avoid some of the more common tropes of the genre, like trying to deliver scares just by killing characters off left and right. I'll admit that the game is short, yet it gave me one of the best graphical adventure experiences I've had in a while, delivering both laughs and intrigue throughout its whole duration.

Oh, it also has a few bugs that can get annoying, just so you know, and the save system isn't quite perfect since if you quit you'll be restarted at the beginning of your current stage"
date: which can mean having to hear dialogue several times since there's no way to skip it. It's annoying
recommended: but since the game is short I'm sure most people will finish it in just one or two days and it won't become a huge issue."

reviewText:
Oxen-free is a story-driven indie poltergeist-inspired teen-drama romp (wow that is a long way of describing it) game. This game is pretty good so far (now beaten), but please read further for a more detailed review!

Firstly..

Controls: The controls for this 2D game with 3D models runs pretty smoothly. No complaints here, standard movement with the keys, just no mention of how to interact with things right at the begining. Easy criteria to get high points for me, but it is suprisingly easy to screw this one up! So for me: 2.0/2.5 for Controls.

Graphics/Smoothness: Graphics are pretty good. Performance runs pretty smoothly and I have no problems at all running the game. No graphical lag at all while playing. Good art-style with the characters and interesting premise using this sort of art to create a teen story out of it. It looks pretty good for an indie game. But with this price tag that it has, you would expect so. For me this gets a 2.0/2.5 (to balance the score)

Gameplay/Bugs: The game itself is fun. It is very story-driven and makes you really think about your decisions. You must answer some questions quicker than others, and there is no sort of kick in the butt" mechanic which tells you to answer quickly or slowly. So
date: you feel as if you need to answer quests as quickly as possible and what ends up happening is that you cut people off (and kind of ruins the immersion of this story-rich game when you are constantly cutting people off)
hoursPlayed:
no complaints and I do not see any complaints on the forums as of yet for bugs. So for me this criteria gets a 2.0/2.5.

The question now is whether or not it is worth 20 bucks which brings us on to the next point..

Value: The game itself is 20 bucks. So with my 1$/Hr value calculations I would need to get 20 hours of gameplay from this game. I believe that I will maybe get half of that
voteText: but it really is still in the air. (Unless they add free DLC or something... hah....) okay
helpfulPercent: enough jokes. But the value itself I do not believe is there for this game. Don't get me wrong
votesTotal: but the value is just not there unless you are really interested in this sort of game. I've played other games that I've paid 20 bucks for and gotten 100+ hours out of them. As for this one
votesFunny: this is not the case unfortunately. So
commentsCount:
this gets a 1.0/2.5 for value.

So here is my score:

7/10

reviewText: Really amazing game so far, but I am having some frame rate issues in the areas with wide-angle environment shots (the forest, for example). I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys visual novels or choose-your-own-adventure type games.

reviewText: To say anything about the 'plot' of this game or where it's going would probably do it a disservice since I enjoyed it all the more for not really knowing what it was gonna be about. So suffice to say that it's a 'walk-n-talk' adventure game with a pretty touching set of characters and rather different vibe than a lot of similar games. When these group of teenagers start out this expedition they are most certainly not friends and things are rather awkard or unpleasant between them in a way that felt very true to life. As you see more of where this game is going you'll find a surprising degree of optional side questy content and some pretty convincing variable dialouge and feedback from characters. Additionally when it wants to be this game is very effectively unnerving and other times when it wants to be very heartwarming or genuine or even emotionally unpleasant in the way fighting with a friend feels in real life. I didn't really know what this was about when I started but I can now highly recommend it to the curious.

reviewText:
So, this game. I cannot even begin to describe all the pros of it, but I don't even need to, as they have all been already mentioned by fellow reviewers. But I will.

What is Oxenfree?
A wonderful story.
Wonderful voice acting.
Wonderful style.
Wonderful soundtrack.
A wonderful loading screen.
A wonderful feeling of accomplishment, together with a wonderful feeling of immersiion and actually being a teenager stuck with some friends (or enemies, if you don't like Clarissa) on an island in some mysterious events.

You feel it going. You cannot not feel it going.
I've been waiting for this game to release ever since the day it has been announced and oh boy (or girl) I am NOT disappointed. For the first time in my life, apparently.

And ye, I hope my feeling of a goty 2016 is not gonna betray me.

reviewText:
So this review comes from someone who has only played about 3 hours of the game. Meaning that there is a ton of stuff I didnt discover yet. This however does not change my opinion on the game.

Overall I can already say that I love playing it. However I love playing it in the evening. I tried playing it today in daylight and it just didnt give me the same feeling with noises and people in the back. So if you want to play it, play it in a dark room by yourself. It gives you the best experience in my opinion.

The game is about a playable story about... Well. Find that out for yourself. Like Undertale this is a game best played without spoilers. Things happen if you let them happen. The whole game depends on your decisions making it into a telltale" game but way different. While Telltale gives you the setting and pushes forward Oxenfree wants the player to explore. Of course there are moments of "plot happens" but that is only to get the game into the direction it has to go no matter if you have done something or not.

I myself know that what I have done at the start of the game couldve been something completly different. I decided to do something and what happened because of that happened. What wouldve happened if I wouldnt have decided to do it? Who knows. I dont.

But now three points that I have noticed that are worth mentioning.

Many people tend to say that the "Teenage Bull" going on in the game is rather stupid and annoying. I however like it alot. It shows that the characters are more than just characters. They ARE Teenagers
recommended:
liking or disliking things. They ACT in a certain way that fits their character. I myself because of that dislike one of the characters mainly because of how he/she acts. And that is the point of it. It gives the game much more depth.

The second thing however is more of a neutral thing. While I already love the game and its graphics there is this one thing that is also very time consuming. Running around on the given maps. Yes he game is about exploration and about you looking here and there to maybe find something but it seems rather slow at times. Nothing bad of course. Just that it may not be for some people.

The last point is a rather neutral one as well.
The graphics of the game look very pretty and also a bit scary at times. Or should I say creepy? I think creepy fits it more. Anyways
hoursPlayed: back to the point. The graphics look very pretty. Yet they have 2D and 3D. 2D as in the background and 3D for the characters. And while the 3D isnt the best I have ever seen it also isnt the worst. If it wouldve been in 2D as well I doubt it wouldve made a big difference.\n\nOverall Oxenfree is already a good game and the experience I had with it so far made it worth playing for me. If you like Storydriven decisionbased freeroam exploration games this is certainly for you."

reviewText:
I've only had a short amount of free time to play but I'm definitely in favor of this title.

Pros:
- Wonderful soundtrack that's very soothing and sets a great atmosphere for the game.
- Characters are well written, pretty diverse in comparison to one another, and have realistic interactions.
- Absolutely amazing voice acting.  Doesn't match up with subtitles all the time, but it feels more genuine that way.
- The radio mechanic is an interesting spin and works well with the storyline.
- The abandoned area settings are a personal plus and give the game a nice aesthetic.

Cons:
- Dialogue options are given very short response times.  Sometimes I don't get the chance to read all of them, or wind up cutting out another character mid sentence when I chose before they fade.
- Walking controls could be a little bit smoother around turns and forks in the road.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I suppose it would first be appropriate to let you know I adore teen dramas. I grew up watching Degrassi, One Tree Hill, 90210 etc. If these themes don't resonate with you as they do I, then I can't speak to whether or not you'll enjoy this game to the same extent I did.

Oxenfree is wonderful. It's mysterious. It's evocative, moody, delightful, terrifying and even heartwarming. It will push you on an emotional rollercoaster through a beautifully hand-painted island fully of incredible and awful sights. The characters are believable teens: annoying, unpredicatable, bratty—but lovable for those reasons.

I'm not going to go into the plot—short of a few very light puzzles, the game is really nothing but exploration-advanced plot—but it is captivating. You'll get as much out of the story as you're willing to put in: if you're not willing to invest yourself in the characters, then it may not resonate with you.

I'd be remiss not to mention the Soundtrack, which mirrors all my thoughts about the game exactly. It's wonderfully melodic, at times saccharine, but then always beautifully, disturbingly dissonant at the right moments. And it's free with the game!

I'd reccomend playing the game in one sitting, preferably in a dark room for maximum effect. A single playthrough shouldn't take more than 6 hours, even if you try to find collectables/optional plot. This shouldn't be too much of a problem though—if you're like me, you'll have a hard time putting it down.

reviewText:
I first heard about this title during E3 2015, it immediately ticked all the right boxes in my head. A lot of regulars in my stream know that I often pick out Indie titles that are absolute gems.

After just completing a playthrough of this it is definitgely one of those games. As far as the Graphics, Sounds and overall presentation of the title I can not think of anything bad to say about it. The game is very dialogue heavy and fully voice acted to the highest quality. I would have liked a few more options but thats just a minor niggle.

It has been a while since I played again and while the credits were rolling I was trying to figure out when I had time to play it again? This is one of those games.

With that being said, this could be the prettiest game in the world however being a story driven adventure how is the actual story? Personally speaking I feel it was very well written, the conversation system is just great. I am looking forward to taking alternate choices on my next playthrough to see how different things end up. Like any good Mystery / Supernatural story the game keeps you wondering what is happening and leaves you with questions right up to the end.

Its hard to really say much more without potential spoilers, for anyone into story rich games this comes highly recommended.
