reviewText: Great story, voice acting, aesthetic and atmosphere. Unfortunatly glitchy, but nothing gamebreaking

Oxenfree is a striking and charming game that beautifully immerses the player into not only the story, but the characters through an outstanding conversational system that surpasses any I've encountered before.

The gameplay is minimal, as to be expected in a story rich game but it delivered more than  I ever could have anticipated with its colossal ambience and its faultless voice acting. The voice acting is so superb, it is what makes Oxenfree so atmospheric and genuine. It is difficult to really articulate exactly what makes it so 'special', it's emotional, it's sincere, it's everything you would wish for in a game heavily dependent upon dialogue and interactions.

The approach to conversations is simple but so engaging that I would be extra cautious to not skip anything, which I must say is fairly rare in games based on heavy dialogue. The characters themselves are quirky and have droves of personality. Character development throughout the game is blended seamlessly and comes naturally and strenghtens the players connection to them.

The walking in Oxenfree isn't tiresome, it is mostly scattered with engaging dialogue and gives the player a chance to soak in the beautiful surroundings as the detail is quite amazing. There is no need for a fast travel system, this isn't Skyrim, it is a STORY RICH game and thus expectations should be altered accordingly.

I will acknowledge, however, that this definitely is not every gamers cup of tea, but it was never meant to be. From my playthrough, it is difficult for me to try and pinpoint a fault. The only slight downside I would say is the price for the length of gameplay, but seeing what Oxenfree has to offer, I would say the price is justifiable.

Oxenfree is a game of beauty, with a perfected conversational system, pragmatic characters that evoke emotion within the player, topped with an obscure story. Each of these elements collectively gives the player incentive to complete it with a sense of urgency, to determine the games outcome. That's what a story rich game really should encompass and what lovers of the genre NEED to play.

reviewText: The part I admired most is the interactive  conversation between friends. The scripts and the voice-acting is emotional and realistic. Characters have conversation while they are walking, and may be interrupted by encountering someones or somethings on their way. The story itself is rather short and not that complex, but the characters do have backgrounds and you will know them better throughout the converastion. The whole atmosphere is great. Just play this game. At first, it was interesting, but by the end, I was fully in it, and while I suppose some of the underlying plot and themes touched on personal notes for me, it left me speechless. Very well done game that plays well and touches on the emotions by allowing you to build a relationship with the game even as you build relationships between the characters.

Oxenfree is, beyond a doubt, one of the most story-driven, well-written, and character-fueled video games I have ever played. Perhaps THE most. And as adventure games are my personal favorite, I hope that's saying a lot.

The central mechanic of the game is  interavtive dialogue (though it sports it's fair share of walking, too), a fact which is well-exploited by Night School Studio. The conversations, which take place everywhere from a haunted island to myterious flashbacks, are creative, amusing, and relatively realistic. Depending on the situation, you'll find yourself talking with anywhere from one to four other individuals, all well-developed and unique characters. Just as in real life, you won't be given the unrealistic conveniance of endlessly pondering what you'll say next, or how you'll respond to an unexpected and perhaps even crucial question posed by one of the other characters, a rather silly reality in many other adventure games. Wait too long to choose a response, and the conversation will move on, leaving you wondering if you were right to remain silent. And even when you do say something, you may never be sure if it was to your benefit, or if it was your undoing.

The story of Oxenfree walks hand-in-hand with this brilliant mechanic, but is, if possible, even more impossibly convoluted. Even as someone who has played it with a fervor, I couldn't possibly spoil the story for you, even if I wanted too, because there are so many different paths to take. One single choice of words can send you spinning in a new direction, discovering one of many possible events and endings. Not all of those endings are good, and perhaps none of them are perfect. As you play as Alex, set amidst the oddities of her teenage friends, slowly descending into the mystery and the madness of a camping trip gone terribly wrong, you'll always be left wondering what just happened, what didn't, and what could have.

If a game that tells a story as deep and mysterious as that found in any thriller film or novel sounds up your ally, and if a title that will make you feel everything from sorrow to happiness and terror to laughter seems right for you, then Oxenfree should indeed grace your wishlist, and hopefully your library. And even though the game is, at most, four or five hours long, it is no longer than it needs to be, and is filled with the various and convoluted possiblities of a second, third, or perhaps even fourth replay.

Oxenfree is a story, deep and dark as any cave, waiting to be explored.

Oxenfree is a very well told story. I can't say much about it without spoiling it, and trust me, it should not be spoiled if you're interested in playing it for yourself.

The important things to note are that the dialogue is wonderfully written, the art and character design work perfectly, and the sound does exactly what it should do in an atmospheric horror game.

The dialogue is what I'd like to focus on further. It's very naturally written and spoken, it's very understandable why the developers are proud of their system. The writing is an example of what you should do with teenage characters, they actually feel real, not like what you'd expect from a middle aged guy thinking teenagers=selfies and that's it.

The only real gripe I can think of is that character movement is a touch slow and there's a few places where other character models get hung up on something and make the following scene either awkward or take a little longer to start while they path to it.

Ordinarily, I'd go for a more in depth review, but the more I say, the more I risk spoiling something. So really, if the trailer catches your attention at all, just buy it and take the time to play it. It's not terribly long, but it will hold your attention for a long while.

Music 10/10
Gameplay 6/10
Story 10/10
Voice acting 8/10

Overall a must play game.

reviewText:
This is a great game with a great story! The voice acting is superb as is the soundtrack.

In the game your dialogue choices appear for such a short time that they disappear before you can even choose one. Also, making dialogue choices interupts what the other characters are saying but you have to do it or lose the chance to choose what you want to say. Initially, I thought this was a problem with quality control but learned this is intentional, intended on mimicking real life conversations. The other characters react by what you choose to say or not to say at all, and sometimes someone gets cut off by another while talking. Realism.

My only complaint: My game crashed 4 times. 3 of them were when the game is about to save progress so I had to replay the section.

This game IS definitely worth the $20.

reviewText:
Alright, so I went into this game blind and I can say I wasn't disappointed from start to finish. The game had some pretty good pacing. I found the radio stuff to be a tad teadious at times, especially near the end of the game. But it wasn't enough to ruin my time with the game as there wasn't a sense of danger as you try to find the right frequency, at least during my playthrough.

The certain aspect of the game I dare not directly mention for the sake of avoiding spoilers also added a sense of ominous-ness to game, as you didn't understand what was going on with that stuff, and it gave you an optional direction to approach the game's story from in my honest opinion.

The game was a tad short, but I think in this case a short, good game is much better than a long-winded bad game. And I spent the whole time thinking the ending wasn't going to live up to all the build up to it, but in the end I was really not disappointed by it. Once I get the time, I'll play through it again.

I picked up the game on a sale so it was really worth the price. So I give this game a solid 9/10. I'd pick it up on a sale like I did, if anything.

reviewText: Worth trying. One of the very few narrative-heavy games that does conversations during movement well. The dialogue is neatly written, voice acting is spot-on and the music makes a great impression. Also, the visuals are really, really good.\n\nThe decisions made during playthrough mattered more than I had initially assumed, and the epilogue wrapped things up nicely. However, I felt like the actual ending was sort of a let-down, and the story in the second half of the game wasn't as strong as the opening hours (which had three or four _really_ great scenes). Still, I implore you to try and figure out the mysteries of the island - despite the game being fairly linear there are a bunch of secrets to uncover that fill out the narrative.

reviewText:
Oxenfree is a new Indie Adventure by newly formed Night School Studio(2014). Who are actually made up of Telltale and Disney alumni! Now that is a quite a combo. Not to mention they are teamed up with Skybound as well!

Oxenfree features a group of kids who unwittingly open a rift during an overnight island party gone horribly wrong. You play as Alex, who has brought her new stepbrother along with you to the party. You determine the story through your dialog choices with Alex. The story and your relationships change based on every choice.

- Great art (Disney alum)
- Soundtrack is well done
- Interesting characters
- Intriguing story/ mystery
- Fantastic world building
- Awesome voice cast
- Gameplay is fun

Gameplay is mostly exploration, dialogue choices and tuning your radio to pick up frequencies. Basic, but it has its own quirk so it's still fun. Lot's to interact with as well so it keeps you on your toes. The game handles conversation in a very unique way. Most of the time you'll be moving while talking and have limited time to respond.

Where this game shines, so far, is in its story, dialog and characters. Each character immediately has their own niche and personality. Some you will love; some you will hate. Oxenfree has a whimsical feel, but soon takes a mysterious turn. It does a great job of building up the tension early on between both the characters and the world. It's certainly hooked me, and I think it will hook you too.

Ultimately, if you enjoy a narrative driven adventure full of mystery and scares, I think you will enjoy this game. IGN reported it clocks in at 3-6 hours, however I'm being told it's more like 7-9 hours. Either way fair amount of time for $20, to me.

If you're looking for gameplay before you buy, why not check out my playthrough!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3cyjuO--KUs

I wanted this review to reflect my first thoughts. I will update half way through and when I've competed the game.

Highly Recommended.

reviewText:
Hard decision, but, in the end, thumbs down
----------------------------------------------

First of all, let's talk about all the good stuff. The aethstetics are awesome, the game looks fantastic, and the music is pretty nice as well.

But, as it is a narration - driven game, let's talk about it's main component.

Honestly, I don't buy it. Here's why:

1) It has a pretty generic cast of you (main character) - generic nerdy/trying to be fun guy - generic normal guy - generic nerdy girl - generic annoying girl.

Which could work, but

2) Unlike, let's say, Life is Strage or any Telltale games or the Longest Journey or anything else, there is absolutely no character development. I would expect to see the characters to be first terrified first by all the unusual things, but then find the courage to go through. Instead, they are literally the same guys that started the journey. Don't get me wrong, the teenage banter is done fine, but it is what it is - just banter, the characters dont open up or progress or improve in any way or form.

reviewText:
I bought Oxenfree because lately I have been really getting into narrative-driven games like Life is Strange or anything by Telltale. Then, after three hours, I ran out of patience and just... stopped. I haven't finished the game, perhaps it gets better in the later stages. But for me it just isn't worth the hassle!

Don't get me wrong, Oxenfree is not a completely bad game, there was certainly effort put into it and some of it paid off. The voice acting is spot-on and the visual style is very interesting, for example. But now let's move on to why I gave this game that big ugly thumbs down.

The game consists mainly of walking around, talking to people and fetch questing. The greatest challenge is finding the right frequency to tune in on your radio so you can advance, which is tedious at best. You can never die or lose in any way (as far as I know), and there are also no intellectual challenges to speak of. So this game basically tests your patience and nothing else.

But who cares about challenge, we are here for the narrative and hard decisions, right? Well, as I said earlier, the voice acting is top notch. But the story itself kind of meanders around, never truly dragging me in. I played this game yesterday and I can only vaguely recollect what I had been doing for those three hours. I can only remember two of the protagonists' names (out of five). I simply wasn't involved, so everything went in and out like a boring lecture.

As for the hard decisions"
date: more often than not I picked arbitrarily or by accident
recommended: because I had no idea that it was decision time. For example
hoursPlayed: at one point you are supposed to choose who will accompany you on your next fetch quest
voteText: but it shows nothing but the characters' names. So I picked one that was the least obnoxious at the time and whoops

votesHelpful: I still wouldn't know who to pick because WHO THE HELL ARE YOU PEOPLE? What am I supposed to base my choice around
votesTotal: I barely remember their names!\n\nSo
votesFunny: to summarize: Art style and voice acting is great
column16: anything else is hardly worth mentioning. I didn't like it.\n\nIt is entirely possible that the game just didn't resonate with me
column17: that this is all just a problem with my personal taste. And seeing how many good reviews this game got
column18: I am inclined to believe that theory. You want to try the game out? By all means
column20: you will probably like it more than I did. But I can not in good conscience recommend it to you."

reviewText:
I was excited after I read so many rave reviews but I dont know - there's something missing about the game. After finishing it I'm still not 100% sure what happened and it didn't feel like there was a plot arc at all. The same stuff kept happening at an even pace until the end and then it was nothing special.

Pros
-Interesting gameplay mechanic
-Characters were engaging to a certain degree
-Art style was unique and gave a real atmosphere to it
- Choice of partner and dialouge was an interesting touch

Cons
-Found myself getting frequently bored
-Stopped connecting with the characters half way through
-There is a puzzle that you do, which isnt too difficult and its interesting when first encountered, but its plot revelance is never explained and you end up doing the same two game mechanics the entire time
-Traveling to and from locations sometimes felt like a chore if the direction wasn't clear, the characters move slowly
-A lot of unanswered question and resolution that doesn't satisfy
-Not worth the full price

Don't get me wrong - I think its an extremely creative idea and I had a decent time playing it, but I kind of regret buying it full price. In the beginning of the story I was extremely excited, edge of my seat - yet as it unraveled I was disappointed to discover there were no new elements. I finished it far more quickly than I thought I would, and overall the feeling of dissatisfaction made me wish I didn't buy it in the first place (again, at least not for $20)

Oxenfree is an awesome short game about teenagers visiting an island to have fun when ghosts interfere with their plans.
What I really liked about the game was the animation, the way the characters talked, their body language and the ability to walk and talk felt real and genuine despite the art style.
You play as Alex, and can choose how you communicate with people, either being a nice empathetic person, or a stone cold ♥♥♥♥♥ (or even a silent protagonist). The character interactions were rich, and were portrayed well, kudos to the voice actors for putting their heart into the work. There isn't much gameplay or action, but honestly I loved the characters so much I didn't care and just wanted to play on to see the end of the game. I recommend this game, but feel free to watch my entire play through and make a judgement yourself. The game has multiple endings and I interpreted as whether we move on with our lives, or hold onto the past.

Fox Plays

reviewText:
For £15 I honestly couldn't recommend this but if it is ever £5 - yeah, sure. I do like narrative driven games (Soma, To the Moon) but despite a promising start, which was quite atmospheric and creepy, I thought it tailed off pretty badly. When it ended it felt like a bit of a surprise as there was no satisfying climax. The dialog was perhaps a bit too two dimensional and teenage and all the back stories were like horror cliches.

I originally liked it's original concept with the walking and talking but, as my speech bubble decisions increasingly felt insignificant to the direction of the story (which, like all bad horror films became pretty dull the second I knew what was going on), it became fairly tedious.

If it ever becomes £5 I'd recommend it as quick, fairly interesting and original game concept that you can complete in an evening but it's not worth £15.

reviewText:
Let me start this off by saying: Oxenfree is a good game. It's better than good. Matter of fact, this might be one of the best games I have ever played.

The narrative is excellent, you can really shape the main character how you want, and I find that is always fun in a game.
The Voice Acting is top notch, every character stands out and is memorable.
The actual story is very good. The art direction is also, very good.

10/10 would finish on a sunday night again.

Do yourself a favor and buy this damn game already. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Pay the 20$ and play this game. Its worth your money and your time.

The artstyle of this game is great, the plot is interesting, and the characters are likeable.

This game just pulls you in, and it doesn't let go. The way the Ghost talks is so badass, and so creepy at the same time. The way it follows you around, and that you can only see it in flashes, just to remind you that it's always watching you, toying with you. It makes you want to know what it is, and what it wants. And the game, generally, isn't that scary. Me, being a complete avoider of the horror genre, didn't think this game was scary enough to make me not want to go pee in the middle of the night. One reason for this is that the Ghost actually talks to you, and explains things pretty early in the game. It's not like you're in the dark throughout the entrie game and at the end you get the information. It doesn't even slowly feed you info to keep you interested. You learn exactly who the Ghost is about an hour into the game. I mean, how many games tell you exactly whats chasing you within the first hour?

Anyway, this game is great, and well worth the 20$. Have fun.


My mothers will see them soon.

reviewText:
Finished in a single sitting. Already planning on re-playing to find all the secrets. It is possible to finish the game without having the full explanation of what was going on, so be prepared for multiple play-throughs!

Awesome story. Characters are excellently constructed. The dialogue is actually really good, which never happens in these games. And the game itself is absolutely gorgeous. Not sure how big an impact your choices have on the ending, but they definitely impact the character relationships at the very least, which is cool.

Ending blew my mind a little bit, to be honest. I'm normally disappointed with the endings of these choice based games (Until Dawn, Life is Strange), but Oxenfree is very well done.

10/10 would binge again.

reviewText:
*Before you read this, I very much recommend that you play this blind, for the optimal experience*


Pros

Essentially(if you want to read a synopsis about the game without spoilers), this game is Life is Strange and Until Dawn meshed into one narrative, with elements from both. I really like it. But, aside from my personal tastes, the art style is gorgeous, with hand-painted, watercolor backgrounds, and relatable characters. There's actually a sense of realism to the decisions you make in the game, where you will have to pick a choice, or none at all. It's like real conversation, where you can cut in and say your piece, or leave the conversation going, without your 10 cents thrown in. Because you never know whether what you say is important or not, you might find yourself being very careful about what you say, or throwing caution to the winds and screwing everything up for yourself. Either way, the fun is the journey, especially with that nifty radio.

The characters have depth to them through their dialogue, and edgy teenage ways. Like someone else said here, their voice acting is absolutely on-point. Some of the music adds quite a fitting sense of tension, as well(gotta have some l33t vaporwave). It adds to the thriller-esque theme, and fits in well with the common horror trope of teenagers goofing off in the middle of nowhere and summoning the Devil or some other riffraff like that. It's a nice twist on the genre, and it's more of a slow-burn creepy, without any jumpscares. Any squeamish people(like me) will be glad to hear that, but the creepy atmosphere is still set here.

Cons

Even with these nice perks of the game, it is an Indie game, and indie games are made with a target audience in mind. I feel as if this was made for fans of Until Dawn and/or Life is Strange. Or, in fact, decision-based games in general. It does involve a lot of walking around, so if you're not much of a fan of walking simulators, then this may not be your cup of tea. Each playthrough is around 6-7 hours, so it may turn many people off because of its steep price, but it's well worth it for the replayability, especially if you buy it while it's on sale.

reviewText: I loved this little game, the art style was really fantastic, the environment was immersive, the characters were interesting. I couldn’t help but feel like I missed so much on my first play through, I’m eager to play it again in a while and spend some time with the more abstract parts of it. I’ll admit I was already hooked from a 15 min gameplay video from Polygon before playing it, but it lived up to my hyped expectations. I would love to see a sequel to this title.

reviewText:
Unfortunately can't recommend this game. It has nice art style (thank God it's not another one of those «8bit pixelart»), and a good soundtrack. In-game effects are interesting. The idea behind the game is interesting too, especially if you like movies like «Frequency», it has something in common.

But the dialogues... are too childish, careless, and lack of immersion. Hey, you've just seen lots of paranormal activities, one of your friends posessed, flying around like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Copperfield on his magic show, and... it's time to talk about dating, your teenage problems, divorce of your parents, etc etc etc. I know it's needed to reveal characters background, but the way it is done is soooo boring. Most of the dialogues in game seemed too unimportant and boring. Now that I've finished the game, I don't want to start another one — because I just can't stand all this teenage chit-chat (or maybe I am too old for this, I don't know).

So, I can praise the technical part of the game, but unfortunately it was «killed» by bad writing. So, if you like to have many meaningless conversations with artificial teenagers — you are going to like this game.

reviewText:
I just don't find the game engaging, the far away view doesn't lend itself to finding the characters or scenery interesting.  The maps are all 2D and blinking circles let you know when you have to interact with something.   So basically you walk around a 2D map interacting with objects and occassionally using  your radio to communicate with the unknown. I've only played two hours but haven't found any of the problems to solve interesting/challenging.

The voice acting is top notch, the dialog is well written and believable.  The problem I have is the only way you get a sense of the characters is through their dialog.  I end up not caring what happens to any of them.

I read some reviews before buying it, and I'm not sure what all the hype is. Maybe I just don't get it...

reviewText: Only got a quarter of the way through the game before I had to stop, it's practically unplayable at this point in time. The FPS is always dropping at random areas, the characters walk VERY SLOOOWLLLY, but the worse part is the NPCs AI. You usually have an NPC character following you while you play the game, and their pathing is very bad and buggy. I constantly find myself waiting miles ahead for the NPC who keeps climbing onto and getting off of the foot of a cliff, or just clinging to it and never moving. For some areas, the screen doesn't scroll all the way with you, keeping you from entering an important house or retrieving an item because you're pretty much moving beyond the edge of the screen.\n\nIn short, don't buy this game or play it until Night School Studio fixes all of the bugs that make it practically unplayable, or else won't have a very pleasant experience with this game.

reviewText:
Ok I know my opinion will go against the status quo, but hear me out.

I loved the story. Seriously, I thought it was great where you could go back in time and possibly save people from death. I also loved the mystery of these other beings, which made me put my Nancy Drew hat on wanting to solve the mystery. Voice acting was AH-MAZING! Really, really great job on that as well.

The problem I had with this was it was extremely SHORT. I know my play time says 9 hours but that is because i went back trying to get all the endings. I really wish it was longer with more challenges or mini games. It would have enriched the story a bit more and it would just amp up the fun (in my opinion). Another thing that makes me want to not recommend this was the controls! While trying to tune the radio for the right frequency drove me mad. MAD, I tell you. And sometimes when I went to go click a choice, the choice that I picked--well wasnt picked. What I mean was I was clicking like mad on a word bubble but it simply didnt seem to realize what i was picking. Thus it made my character say or do nothing. If these things were fixed or added on to, then I would give a thumbs up. Its just that I think there is so much more potential to this game but with its short play time...i just cant recommend it (at the current price or even the normaly price of $20.)

reviewText:
Oh, boy... another one of “those” games... The kind where you know the protagonist has gone through some emotional trauma because she dyed her hair blue. The kind where, despite seeing your friends possessed and committing suicide a scant few minutes ago, there's always time to stop and take a group selfie and banter about mundane teenage problems. If this is the new age of video game entertainment, where we fully embrace the self-imposed inferiority complex when stacked against other mediums that are better suited to telling nuanced long form narratives, why does the writing feel like it was cobbled together from the Dawson's Creek trash bin? Is the lateral move from a fourteen year old male demographic to a fourteen year old female demographic (who aren't capable of playing traditional games) really a sign of progress? Why do these teenagers talk like they're thirty, but don't understand simple concepts like what constitutes a stepbrother? Why do they start the game as stereotypical Diablo Cody characters, survive what would be a life-changing night for anyone... and end the game as stereotypical Diablo Cody rejects? Sigh...

To be fully honest: I'm not the intended audience for Oxenfree. I heard a few rumblings about a new horror game where it was best to go in as fresh as possible to get the most out of it, so I took the bait and bought it on blind faith. That was a bad move. Immediately I began to have PTSD episodes of Gone Home, where it became clear this game was made for entry level, angsty preteens and creepy, middle aged academic critics who questionably identify with them. To be clear: I'm not against “casual” games, or narrative focused games, or even coming of age stories, nor do I want to take anything away from anyone who enjoys them... but if that's your thing... demand more than what Oxenfree has to offer.

I quite liked the hand painted backgrounds of Oxenfree. They stand in sharp contrast to the PS2-looking, low polygon character models that frequently clip through each other. There can be a problem with scale and navigation caused by the art, as some paths aren't clear and you can often outrun the camera. The game probably wouldn't be pushing any limits on a phone, but overall it's pleasant to look at. You will be referring to your map quite often, however, and that suffers from the same problems with scale and determining pathways. Scattered around the island are some collectibles in the form of small piles of rocks, and these can be unnecessarily difficult to spot: they're tiny and often almost indistinguishable from the background, or they're off-camera...

The clashing art style is exemplary of the game itself. Oxenfree feels like a handful of disparate ideas thrown against a wall, and they don't mesh particularly well together. Some of the horror elements are kind of cool, but they're completely destroyed by the pacing necessary to tell a poor teenage melodrama. The relationships of the characters could have been interesting to explore, but the supernatural elements (and their lack of concern about them) along with generally poor development and payoff make the script seem secondary. The exploration of the island could have been satisfying, but it's bogged down with the clunky dialogue... Nothing ever really gels, and none of Oxenfree's parts are very strong on their own merits. I also ran into a couple notable bugs. Once the AI just up and broke on me, leaving my character stuck at a door while her much needed friend just stared at her, causing me to reload a save from ten minutes prior and relive a scene I didn't care about the first time all over again. Another time a female companion's dialogue was replaced with an off-screen male character's voice for a lengthy line. That was actually pretty funny and unfortunately the most entertainment I got out of Oxenfree.

reviewText: IGN hyped this game like it was the second coming of the Indie scene in 2016, but after walking through it for nearly 2 hours I can see this is pure garbage. Oxenfree is a slow 2.5D walking simulator, with very very minimal gameplay which basically consists of talking to idiot teens, climbing hills and tuning the frequency of a useless radio. The game looks beautiful, it has a good soundtrack, but how on earth is anyone supposed to just walk about for 6-7 hours is beyond me. Avoid or buy for $2 on the next Steam sale.

reviewText: A great adventure game. Do not spoil your experience, just dive right in.\nMy playthrough lasted for roughly 4 hours. Money and time well spent IMHO.
If you love story and having your mind blown this is for you.

Wow, this was such an awesome experience. I really liked this game. It kept me engaged and locked in the whole time. The plot was suspenseful and engaging. The characters were really fun and quite interesting. I really liked Alex in particular. She was easily likeable, with an easygoing yet subtle, fun yet considerate, and real personality, despite being almost completely player defined. The conversations between the characters and their relationships felt surprisingly organic and fluent. It was a joy to listen to banter and build relationships with people. It was even more of a joy participating in banter (it was so fun and made me feel in compete control of Alex. Pretty cool). They did an excellent job making interesting, fun, natural, and immersive character interactions. This is my favorite part of the game. Furthermore, I just love the amount of dialogue and plot choices that the game enables me to make. It's like I am defining almost everything Alex said, acted, or even felt about situations. This is one of the first games that made me feel like I had that level of freedom and extensive control over my own character's interactions. I just wish you didn't have to interrupt people talking all the time because you're afraid to run out of time to pick a dialogue option. I would've liked it if they gave us more time to respond, but included a [...] option for the times when you want to remain silent. The voice acting, I have to say, is so organic and natural, and immersively delivered. It never felt off or jarring. It just flowed perfectly. Wonderful job done by the voice actors, especially Alex's.

I love how the plot kept me on your toes, immersing me in a comfortable and familiar environment, yet contrasting that with doses of supernatural events. The atmosphere is full of captivating suspense and enticement; it really draws you in. The plot just gets more and more intriguing, more and more intense as it progresses.

I liked the graphical art style too. Not too over-the-top stylish (like a lot of indie games with their black and white, shadows, and artistic partial effects). They definitely took a more subtle, yet really nice approach to the art style that I appreciate. It's colourful. Not rainbowy or particularly vibrant, yet not monochrome either. It's really easy on the eyes.

I'm not a fan of platformers. So I'm also not too keen on 2D sidescrollers. But this game, with its smooth mechanics and controls, along with its nice art style and 2.5D world, made the experience of traversing the world quite enjoyable. The conversations also made it a lot more interesting. The controls were very smooth, simplistic, and easy to adapt. I found it a lot more comfortable with a controller, that's for sure. My only complaint here is really just the lack of guide to the controls. I didn't know how to jump or interact with something, or use the radio in the beginning. A few times when I needed to. I just ended up mashing keys until I figured it out. Yes, there's a few popups that come up, but it's quite sparse and easily missed. I would've liked if we had a list of controls and had access to keybindings. Also, followers got occasionaly stuck in the environment as part of some pathing bugs, which prevented the plot from progressing. I had to reload several times.

Which brings me to the next point. The menus. The options menu is lacking. Where is the audio adjustment for changing dialogue, sound effect, and music volume? How do I enable Vsync? How can I customize my level of graphical detail? And of course, as I've mentioned before, where is the controls menu and keybindings option? It would've definitely helped to be able to access some more settings. I would've also liked a multiple save files option so I can explore different narrative paths and choices, or undo some of my actions. There's really no easy way to do that without having to start over.


But these are nitpicks, really. It didn't take away from my enjoyment of the game. My biggest gripe (which isn't really a complaint as much as a preference) is with the ending. Although I won't say that it's bad, because it's quite cleverly conceived and well crafted, but the ending is one thing that I really disliked. The ending just felt disjointed from everything that was worked towards in the game. I won't elaborate, but it just didn't feel like a true conclusion" or gave adequate closure to the main plotline that was being played out. It took away from the value of everything I did in the game
date: and made that feel insignificant.\n\nBut I loved this game. I loved the story
hoursPlayed: I loved the banter and dialogues
voteText: and I loved the sense of freedom and extensiveness in Alex's character. If I could describe this game in one word

reviewText: Brilliant game and excellent story.\n\nI loved the idea of using the radio to tune into non-existing radio stations.
Deep storyline matched by sound, art, visuals, and narration gameplay" - the first of it's kind I've seen. Will be playing it a 2nd time through to see what other storylines I missed!"

I recently played through Oxenfree, yet another game set in my Cascadian home that plays to the sinister magic of the region; whatever keeps the Californians from moving here, I suppose.

Like most of the single-player games I enjoy, Oxenfree is heavily invested in its narrative. The title is fairly gameplay light; I’d almost go so far as to call it a walking simulator, if that didn’t seem to be such a weird characterization for what’s effectively a 3-D sidescroller. Still, the gameplay will mostly be comprised of exploring the game’s island as you progress through the plot, using your handheld radio to tune into anomalies found throughout the map.

Oxenfree draws its clearest inspirations from teen horror flicks of the 80s and 90s, centering on a group of teens who venture to an empty island to enjoy a night of fun. As you’d expect, it doesn’t take long before their plans are upended and the weirdness sets in.

The game would best be categorized as a psychological horror title, relying on the strength of its characters to build tension instead of cheap jump scares. Featuring a team of veteran voice actors, the dialogue delivery is some of the best I’ve experienced in a game, notable in particular for the timing of characters’ lines. The flow of interaction finds realism through the ways characters constantly interrupt and talk over each other like actual people, something I’d never known I was missing in video games until now. Beyond the quality, dialogue delivers on the quantity front as well; there’s hardly a moment where someone isn’t going on about something, be it the characters’ relationships with each other or the events unfolding around them. The game’s conversation system includes a choice and consequence element where your choices will decide how characters view you and the way the story progresses and eventually ends.

There are several mysteries to be unraveled as you progress through Oxenfree, and they won’t all be laid out clearly just by following the main plot. As you journey through the vacant island, you’ll find clues to its history hidden along the way, challenging the player to piece together the full story in their head.

Despite being a horror title, I wouldn’t really characterize Oxenfree as scary. It’s certainly an engaging and thrilling experience, but there was never any point in this game where I felt like I was in danger of having a heart attack; this is likely a result of the aforementioned avoidance of jump scares. If you’re the type who usually avoids horror games, I wouldn’t rule the game out purely on that basis.

For the bottom line, Oxenfree features a solid story with excellent dialogue, engaging conversation choices, and enough mystery to keep you interested. My single-sitting playthrough of the game took around 4 hours, which does introduce a question of value for a $20 title. While I would unreservedly recommend playing the game, your personal value judgments may make this one to pick up when it goes on Steam sale.

A Fasntastic atmospheric game with a great story.

It is a good game worth a mention if you like a good short story. Few games nowadays actually try to make you feel something for the characters or manage to do it in such a small amount of time. Bravo, devs, you did well with what you had. If money is your concern, wait for a discount and pick it up. It's worth a small part of your weekend at the very least.

Oxenfree is a solid game. The story is interesting and quite original, you'll find yourself wanting to know more about the island, and the strange happenings that is occuring to your own character (Alex) and four other friends that your on this mystery island adventure with.

The dialogue is actually very natural, entertaining, and comedic. They really nailed this important part of the game. As a result I connected with all of the characters, maybe not Nona so much... But otherwise everyone has very distintive personalities, and people you may judge early on you can have a completely different opinion of later on in the game.

I've only played through once so far, and I feel like doing it again. So that's a good sign right? Repeat value, the alternative ending outcomes works well in it's favor.

It's not really scary, at all. But I don't think this was even an intent with the dev's, this is very much a casual indie game, and I loved this approach.  Also the game really isn't a challenge in conventional ways. It simply forces you to make decisions which can possibly impact your friends lives in negative or positive ways, so if your into that sort of thing you'll probably love this game.

The art style is like a 10/10 lovely asthetic, it brings the world to life, seriously amazing job by their artists.

The soundtrack feels very carpenter inspired, with also what feels like a bit of a nod to disasterpeace. The composition are very minmalistic in nature, they never become to busy or present to completely pull you out of the immersive experience. The composer nailed the time period and atmosphere, but also showed a lot of restraint, yet the music never gets tiresome or to repatative. I loved how he processed all of the synth sounds with added tape delay giving that lovely wabble from the fluttering.

The sound effects are also spot on.

If you like mystery games, then I'm pretty sure you are going to want to experience this.

Rating: 8/10

Pretty good. Decent story & dialogue, very good voice acting. And the online mechanics are... interesting. No spoilers.
Also the radio mechanics are fun. You get out what you put in. You want to blitzkrieg the story points? Good for you. You want to listen to all the radio tours, find the anomalous signals, collect the hidden lore bits? You'll get more playtime and more enjoyment out of the experience.

My only complaint is the apparent lack of consequence. I chose to go save one of my 'friends' first, and expected to find the other turned into red paste. But no, he was a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥, had a bit of extra dialogue but then carried on like nothing ever happened. All that changed was the pie charts at the end put me in the ♥♥♥♥ category.

Is it worth full price? Maybe. It's only a 5-6hr game, although there is a bit of replay value in exploring the different dialogue options & collecting all the collectible collectibles.
On sale? Go ahead, have you got anything better to spend a tenner on?

I really enjoyed this game. The gameplay itself is mostly selecting dialogue options, walking and making decisions, with the ocassional and simple mini-game thrown in, but don't let that put you off.

The story and voice acting are fantastic, and I felt as though I was playing through a pretty decent and interesting movie, heavily influenced by my decisions.

Despite my 5 hour play time, it took me just under 4 hours to finish.

Highly recommended if you enjoy a good story, but don't expect too much in terms of gameplay; that's not what this is.

Well, let's see:
- graphics - nice backgrounds/effects (awesome looking radio tunner), but sometimes cliffs/paths are too darks to see.
- gameplay - a part of it is standart adventure game loop (go there, look at that, find this). Some parts are linear but there are choices. It's character-driven game, so you need to (or not) care for relationships between them. But the part where it shines most is the radio mechanics. A gorgeous radio tuner scale popups when press a button and you can tune to different frequencies. It simulates an analogue radio, so you never get a perfect singal. There are some interferences, sometimes static, sometimes something important. Some messages needs to be written down (get some pen and paper). It's awesome.
- AI - what AI? Where there is only one type of AI there - other NPCs follow main character. Nothing special, except that they can get stupid and blocked on cliffs/jumps. But Devs said they are working on fixing that.
- sound - brilliant. There are some jump scares, there are some environmental sounds. And there is a radio and everything related to it. Brilliant.
- music - very solid soundtrack. So solid that it's worth buying it separatly. It fits the game and it's good to listend outside the game.
- plot/worldbuilding/characters - I can't say anything about this without spoling it. If you are afraid that this is a game about idot teenagers" then don't - they don't follow most of the stereotypes. They are actually nice and I think they will spawn some fanbase (There are already some ships sailing ^_^ ).
Overall I really liked it. Yes it's short
date: but you can play it more then once (again - can't say why)."

I wish I could recommend this game five times over. Yes, some of the teenage drama/dialogue can be a bit much, but the characters all felt unique and fully fleshed out. There are a few moments that are legitimately scary, and the music and overall story are both great. I played it twice to test the quality of the replay, and I'd say it isn't as great the second time around, even though I got a different ending. Still, it's worth it still to go through it more than once. That said, even though I don't seen this game being one I visit multiple times, I feel it was worth the price. Just a great experience.

This is only enhanced by the amazing quality of voice acting. Most games have at least one bad/ok voice actor, but all of the acting in Oxenfree is top notch. Normally I'd say $15 is the best price for this game, and is what I bought it at, but after playing it, and considering the level of production value put into it, $20 is far from an absurd price, despite its relatively short length. I honestly think this is a perfect game for what it set out to achieve. 10/10

Also the radio mechanics are fun. You get out what you put in. You want to blitzkrieg the story points? Good for you. You want to listen to all the radio tours, find the anomalous signals, collect the hidden lore bits? You'll get more playtime and more enjoyment out of the experience.

My only complaint is the apparent lack of consequence. I chose to go save one of my 'friends' first, and expected to find the other turned into red paste. But no, he was a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥, had a bit of extra dialogue but then carried on like nothing ever happened. All that changed was the pie charts at the end put me in the ♥♥♥♥ category.

Is it worth full price? Maybe. It's only a 5-6hr game, although there is a bit of replay value in exploring the different dialogue options & collecting all the collectible collectibles.
On sale? Go ahead, have you got anything better to spend a tenner on?

I really enjoyed this game. The gameplay itself is mostly selecting dialogue options, walking and making decisions, with the ocassional and simple mini-game thrown in, but don't let that put you off.

The story and voice acting are fantastic, and I felt as though I was playing through a pretty decent and interesting movie, heavily influenced by my decisions.

Despite my 5 hour play time, it took me just under 4 hours to finish.

Highly recommended if you enjoy a good story, but don't expect too much in terms of gameplay; that's not what this is.
Oxenfree makes a good case that Alan Wake could've worked as an indie game.\n7/10, would play Truth or Slap" on that shingle beach again."
Simply perfect.

Well, let's see:
- graphics - nice backgrounds/effects (awesome looking radio tunner), but sometimes cliffs/paths are too darks to see.
- gameplay - a part of it is standart adventure game loop (go there, look at that, find this). Some parts are linear but there are choices. It's character-driven game, so you need to (or not) care for relationships between them. But the part where it shines most is the radio mechanics. A gorgeous radio tuner scale popups when press a button and you can tune to different frequencies. It simulates an analogue radio, so you never get a perfect singal. There are some interferences, sometimes static, sometimes something important. Some messages needs to be written down (get some pen and paper). It's awesome.
- AI - what AI? Where there is only one type of AI there - other NPCs follow main character. Nothing special, except that they can get stupid and blocked on cliffs/jumps. But Devs said they are working on fixing that.
- sound - brilliant. There are some jump scares, there are some environmental sounds. And there is a radio and everything related to it. Brilliant.
- music - very solid soundtrack. So solid that it's worth buying it separatly. It fits the game and it's good to listend outside the game.
- plot/worldbuilding/characters - I can't say anything about this without spoling it. If you are afraid that this is a game about idot teenagers" then don't - they don't follow most of the stereotypes. They are actually nice and I think they will spawn some fanbase (There are already some ships sailing ^_^ ).
Overall I really liked it. Yes it's short
date: but you can play it more then once (again - can't say why)."

reviewText: A delightfully streamlined adventure game that combines great art direction and voice work with a wonderfully smooth gameplay experience.\n\nIn other words, well worth the price of admission.

Oxenfree is a story based adventure game with some light puzzle solving.  In a sense, its like undertale, where you need to experience it, rather than watch it to make the most of it.  I spent around 5 hours playing it grabbing all the collectables, so if your intereted in bang for you buck, there are better alternatives as replayablility is limited.  Certain decisions will be tracked and compared at the end, and you may end up impeding or influencing other players.  Art style is fantastic, a nice 'fairy tale' vibe really helps build the world your on, but it can be a little dark in areas with key interactable objects hard to notice.  Voice acting is superb, really nothing much more can be said.  Story is very nice, and character development is executed extremely well, with everyone changing naturally based on your actions.  Soundtrack is good, helps set the mood for the story while not being dominating.\n\nOverall, if you want a good story focused game, this is a great choice.  Now if you'll excuse me, Ren's taking me to this yearly excusion on edwards island, and i've got to pick up my new step brother Jonus.  Hope he's not mean or anything..

I recently played through Oxenfree, yet another game set in my Cascadian home that plays to the sinister magic of the region; whatever keeps the Californians from moving here, I suppose.

Like most of the single-player games I enjoy, Oxenfree is heavily invested in its narrative. The title is fairly gameplay light; I’d almost go so far as to call it a walking simulator, if that didn’t seem to be such a weird characterization for what’s effectively a 3-D sidescroller. Still, the gameplay will mostly be comprised of exploring the game’s island as you progress through the plot, using your handheld radio to tune into anomalies found throughout the map.

Oxenfree draws its clearest inspirations from teen horror flicks of the 80s and 90s, centering on a group of teens who venture to an empty island to enjoy a night of fun. As you’d expect, it doesn’t take long before their plans are upended and the weirdness sets in.

The game would best be categorized as a psychological horror title, relying on the strength of its characters to build tension instead of cheap jump scares. Featuring a team of veteran voice actors, the dialogue delivery is some of the best I’ve experienced in a game, notable in particular for the timing of characters’ lines. The flow of interaction finds realism through the ways characters constantly interrupt and talk over each other like actual people, something I’d never known I was missing in video games until now. Beyond the quality, dialogue delivers on the quantity front as well; there’s hardly a moment where someone isn’t going on about something, be it the characters’ relationships with each other or the events unfolding around them. The game’s conversation system includes a choice and consequence element where your choices will decide how characters view you and the way the story progresses and eventually ends.

There are several mysteries to be unraveled as you progress through Oxenfree, and they won’t all be laid out clearly just by following the main plot. As you journey through the vacant island, you’ll find clues to its history hidden along the way, challenging the player to piece together the full story in their head.

Despite being a horror title, I wouldn’t really characterize Oxenfree as scary. It’s certainly an engaging and thrilling experience, but there was never any point in this game where I felt like I was in danger of having a heart attack; this is likely a result of the aforementioned avoidance of jump scares. If you’re the type who usually avoids horror games, I wouldn’t rule the game out purely on that basis.

For the bottom line, Oxenfree features a solid story with excellent dialogue, engaging conversation choices, and enough mystery to keep you interested. My single-sitting playthrough of the game took around 4 hours, which does introduce a question of value for a $20 title. While I would unreservedly recommend playing the game, your personal value judgments may make this one to pick up when it goes on Steam sale.
A Fasntastic atmospheric game with a great story.
Great game that captures the relationship of a group of teenagers quite well and weaves it into a horror/supernatural storyline. The music fits and the game really gets you hooked. Go and try :).
I'm loving it so far. It has great art work, character voicing, and story i would love to play more games like this.\nRecomend LvL: 100%

Short review
This talkative game is really immersive between the issues of a bunch of teenagers, where you have some liberty to bend  the characters' relations, and a horror ghost story. Really catchy, this somehow short game will take your breath thanks to astonighing graphics and its storyline.
I recommand you this game. Except if you're really a fan of this kind of game, wait for steam sales; but don't miss it.

Long review
Oxenfree is a promenade between teenage's struggles and a ghost horror story. As the game doesn't really have any gameplay challenge (it's more a talkative game), the atmosphere is really immersive. The different answers you choose will bend the relations between the 5 characters, even if the main arc won't change (not I've noted). I've really like how you can be submerge by the game atmosphere and storyline. I've really felt transport in a mix between my nostalgia for my own teenage years, my interest in psychologiy horror stories and some philosophical though (remind me somehow the comics Bell's Theorem" by Schulltheiss because of the "time" problematic and the sunken submarine)

Playing with the radio (the main feature of the game) is really original and well integrated in the game. We can also catch some old radio and get some old music - maybe the background music could have been only through the radio.

+ said it would took me 4 hours I played 9 in my first playthrough

- you can get lost very easily (they show you a map but after that it's no longer accessable which is pretty annoying!)

- 20 € is a very high price. But you pay 5€ for a starbucks coffee or 12€ for a movie in the cinema, you can play a game again and again. I can tell that there is a lot of work behind it.

I would love to see more games like this!

If you're looking for a well done 6 hours of play, I recommend Oxenfree, a great weird fiction tale and well worth my loss of sleep tonight. I kind of want to play it again already.

My only cons are:
-It is very easy to interupt the witty and well delivered dialog
-And often easy to miss the chance to pick a dialog option while listening to charaters
-No control mapping in the options menu (took me forever to learn I could use the radio with right click [much better than shift])
-More!! Make Oxenfree 2 or DLC if the quality can be met or surpassed. Or just make more weird fiction games.

The game gets a 8/10 from my end.

+graphics- beautiful and unique viewpoint throughout the game
+the choice of your responses - gives the feel that you actually impact the conversations
+atmosphere - throughout playing, there's different challenges which give it a great vibe
+the story: great thrills and theme
+the percentage shown at the end that compares your choices to other people's choices

- the conversations: the characters in game talk A LOT, which means a lot of focus on giving your response in a small time frame(you can only choose so long until you remain quiet without having given a response)
- the story: it starts off great but eventually ends a bit, freelanced/abstract and the ending isn't really a proper 'lets close this game off' ending so...left me hung out to try a bit
- walking distances: you gotta walk a lot and cannot short cut, which takes a lot of time especially when the co-star next to you keeps talking about random stuff.

It's great fun but it didn't blow my mind. If you like 1-3 hours of abstract atmospheric fun, go for it but don't expect a mind blowing ending or a twist in the story.

TLDR: It's like If Kentucky Route Zero was finished, and Broken Age's second half was good. It's SO PRETTEH, SO AMAZING. Thrilling story, interesting characters, nice music, wonderful atmosphere - ahhh. And I love the art style!!

Oxenfree is masterful in every way. The story creates this eerie ambience with bits of hilarity thrown in at every corner. It's heavily emotionally driven story. The gameplay is creative and quirky (3D meets 2D side scroller?) The choices and different endings makes the replay value high. Be prepared to face the Evil.

I wish I could recommend this game five times over. Yes, some of the teenage drama/dialogue can be a bit much, but the characters all felt unique and fully fleshed out. And in a way, their personalities added to or highlighted the tension of the atmosphere. The juxtoposition of a bunch of silly teens stuck on this terrible island just works. There are a few moments that are legitimately scary, and the music and overall story are both great. I played it twice to test the quality of the replay, and I'd say it isn't as great the second time around, even though I got a different ending. Still, it's worth it still to go through it more than once. That said, even though I don't seen this game being one I visit multiple times, I feel it was worth the price. Just a great experience.

One of the nicest adventure/exploration games I've played in a long time.
It doesn't focus on icon puzzles or wild quests. It just tells a very nice story, in a very nice setting.

If you like action, you've come to the wrong place.. but if you enjoy a good evening with a book, then this game will give you what you crave: An awesome, well presented story.

This is an extremely well-written interactive story. Let me emphasise that last bit: INTERACTIVE STORY. There's not much in the way of replayability and gameplay in this one, but this story has VERY well written and voice-acted dialogue.\nThe story is a pretty linear, but there's a fair bit of character interaction that the player can influence. Definitely recommend buying this one if you like interactive stories.

TL;DR - This game is simply amazing. It's a very story-driven choice based game with amazing voice acting and dialog options that actually feel significant. The price point may be high for those expecting more than 4-5 hours of content, but I definitely recommend it at normal price. If on sale, it's a must buy.

Oxenfree is a very enjoyable experience. It was made by some former Telltale devs and this becomes very clear as time goes on. Characters form opinions of you based on your dialog choices and you can use this element to build up or tear down relationships. The impact of some choices comes off as very clear, but others are so subtle you wouldn't recognise that it had an affect if a little bubble didn't pop up over the characters head. While the game is fairly linear in its story, you can explore different areas at any time and progress at your own pace. While exploring you have the option to learn about the world and gather various collectibles. All of which are completely optional and only seek to expand on the story of the game. They are also not very hard to find. Some require a watchful eye and others the deciphering of some simple word puzzles.

On a different note, the atmosphere of this game is fantastic. I found myself playing the game at night and in the dark in order to get the full effect of the game. The supernatural elements are very well done and keep the game from being your typical walking simulator"

helpfulPercent:
and point-and-click adventure. And it ends up being better for it. By combining all these elements you get a truly unique experience that's really hard not to like.

reviewerDisplayName: I throw rocks at retarded kids
reviewText: I was expecting a decent game but got an amazing one. Couldnt have been better!

Loading this game up, and pressing start begins a journey that you can't comprehend with a single playthrough.

As an artist I want to begin with the visual beauty of this game. It's gorgeous. Every part of the island is unique and haunting while fitting the comicbook style visuals. Or should I say the 90s Saturday morning cartoon style-of which you recorded on a single vhs too many times and the magnetic strip started wearing out around the edges... It all meshes and adds to the atmosphere. It's eerie and scary without jumpscares and loud sounds.

Which rolls us into the audio; being the true genius of Oxenfree. I don't know much about the time period the radio tunes us in to, but the clips that were chosen, from old wailing poka to bugs bunny, are all set to make you feel off, to add to the atmosphere you're wandering through. The dialogue, and the warped hollow sounds of the spirits, and the whispers caught over the airwaves, are all perfect.

I can't exactly talk about dialogue without getting into gameplay. Because participating in conversations is one of the major points of gameplay. Like a Bioware or Tell Tale game you have multiple things you can say in conversations. You learn different things about the characters in each playthrough, because you don't have the time to stick around and keep chatting. You effect your relationships with your friends with rarely the chance to truly make amends. And I wont mention how your choices actually effect the ending. Because they do. And there's some mind melting endings you can dredge up. The other major point of gameplay is the radio. Using a Steam controller, I found the radio puzzles simple to solve, but in a third playthrough I found that solving them too fast cut off dialogue I hadn't heard. Moving around the map doesn't take too much time, the only part of the map I hate traversing is climbing up and down the radio tower... And there's only been one glitch I've encountered so far, and it's not gamebreaking.

The plot is deep. And while I say a couple endings are mind melting, the adventure you go on is what really makes Oxenfree spectacular. At every step there's character interaction, something to learn about the island, or the spirits toying with you. There has been so much detail and care put into the world that half way through your frist run you think you're piecing together what really happened, only to realize that while the spirits do have a story, they aren't the problem.

Oxenfree has a lot to offer, if you don't want to give the masterminds behind this beautiful game the twenty bucks they earned, you can wait for a sale. I wont judge. But aside from a few minor glitches that'll probly get fixed, and a lackluster collectathon I can't reccomend this game enough.
A creepy story driven and highly adictive game!

I love this game, it has to be one of my new favorites. Amazing characters, great voice acting, and the art is beautiful. Not to mention the soundtrack is super fitting. I finished my first play through today and plan on playing again to see what other endings I can get.

There's something really special about this game. The voice acting and dialogue are great! And the story line so far is super creepy. Makes me want to replay it to really pay attention to things I might have missed or dialogue options I didn't pick. Great game!

This is probably one of the best horror games I've ever seen.

Oxenfree focuses more on atmosphere and story than actual horror, but believe me, there are still some genuinely scarey bits. It's a really good game if you want to ease into horror games; it's almost like a movie with a choose your own adventure twist. It's also a really neat game for people who can't play video games really well or don't want to fight in their games. Fighting seems to be a big thing in most horror games, and although this isn't the first game to do that, it's still a realitively fresh thing.

The story is actually pretty creative, although does carry a few tired tropes like  that Alex's brother is dead and she (and Clarisse) have to deal with it along with the spooky happenings  but it's not too distracting or even that bad. Most of the tropes are written so well I can't really say it's a bad thing, only that it's not original. Some things in the story seem a little dated, but again, it's not too distracting. It's a mostly timeless game yet it can take place in a pretty small span of years, which is hard to do. They take full advantage of this  by using smart phones to take pictures of the spooky spots and showing them in a polariod picture with the ghost in the background of the photo . It's not only an interesting disign, but also has a small role in world building.

The art is amazing. The backgrounds and sets: absolutely sets the mood. The little photos that are taken from time to time have a nice aesthetic feel to it. The character animations are wonderful: shifting, moving their hands, and walking realistically and showing emotion through body language rather than facial expressions.

One major problem I had with this game is the amount of talking, which is all written and voice acted perfectly, but can be pretty long and drawn out. If you're like me and are pretty distractable and/or get restless just sitting and reading/listening or moving from point A to point B without much action, you'll need to be in the right mood to play it. If lots of dialogue is you're thing, go for it. Otherwise, find another game that's more simulating.

A small tip for the above issue: if things get too boring or slow, pause and walk around a bit, eat, splash water on your face, whatever. Just do things to break up the amount of time you're just sitting and reading/listening.

One thing I noticed off the bat was that the voice acting is pretty bad. Little nit picky things that annoy me in this game is that people sigh way to much and no one sounds genuine, like the voice actors are trying to force emotions and they come out weird.\n\nI would only recommend this game when/if it goes on sale.

Fully enjoyed the whole game! Something new on the gameplay where it felt like a real life situation like how the characters talk to each other and we had to choose what we should respond in a short period of time to cut in a conversation. haha very fascinating! Love how the storyline is also unpredictable. Definitely well put together.

Great decision-based game with an interesting story! Feels almost like the Life is Strange of early 2016, which isn't a bad thing that it has a similar style in terms of gameplay, because the way it executes it is unique and fun. Definently would recommend if you like games with a Life is Strange sorta gameplay style. Also, love the art style, it's absolutley amazing.

Oxenfree is an emotionally charged game that cleverly takes advantage of player-choice mechanics.

There's much to be said about the positives of this game: whimsical graphics, an eerily beautiful soundtrack, well-defined characters with fantastic performances by their voice actors. The story follows Alex in such a way to reveal important information about her and her situation without spelling it out for the player, and the player gets to know Jonas in the same way that Alex does. The game isn't *terrifying*, but I admit I was startled quite a few times while playing -- enough to keep me on my toes, but not too much to make me anxious about playing.

Things I didn't like about the game? Well, there's not much to dislike, to be honest. I guess the speed at which the characters walk and climb objects is annoying, but a lot of the time, the dialogue fills in that space, and makes it less boring. The mechanics of the radio aren't super fun, either. It's an essential portion of the game, yet I had issues with the radio closing out when I was turning the dial, and making me repeat sequences of tunings over again. This, in itself, would be a harmless glitch if it didn't take forever to change the channel on the radio. It made discovering the anomalies" disinteresting to me since it just took so long to walk to the rocks and then tune the radio to the right station. But maybe I'm just too impatient.

A lot of choice-based games seem to streamline their endings (Life is Strange
recommended: is guilty of this); I didn't feel this was the case with Oxenfree. I felt like the things I said did have an impact on the game
hoursPlayed: and ultimately its end. And like I mentioned before
voteText: the voice acting was phenomenal. Personally
helpfulPercent: I would've been a bit more choked up about the situation than these characters were
votesTotal: to each their own. It's refreshing to play a storyline that doesn't have romance thrown in just to attract players -- Alex stands alone
votesFunny: and her relationship with other characters seems on a strictly platonic level. This means no gimmicky love crap

column17: I don't think I would've been so bothered by it.\n\nSo what do I want to see more of? GAMES LIKE THIS. Real characters with interesting personalities
column20: and simplistic yet gorgeous graphics make this game really come into its own. Night School Studio really delivered on this one
column21: and I am already hoping to see them pursue other games of this style.\n\nAll in all

column23: I say go for it. You've got to be willing to listen to the story

reviewText: I really like this game and  I would definetly recomend it.

Amazing design, colours and story, a visual pleasure. Kind of walking through a creepy teenage horror movie, but still not too jumpscary. The dialouge can be a bit frustrating, but it still drives the story on. I kind of wish it would last longer. Good thing is you can be a nerd and go back for hidden secrets and alternate outcomes for the various situations.

Very intuitive playstyle, Characters are deep and interesting, the plot itself is pretty epic, and the feel of the game is the best. I would reccomend this to any horror lovers, or anyone who likes mystery. It also has a very complete rebellious teenage soul to it.
Loving this! The story and characters are rich and interesting, the athmosphere goes from cute art to creepy very quickly and the radio static mechanic is genuinely creepy at times. Would recommend!

Absolutely reccommend! The art style is beautiful, the soundtrack is gorgeous, the story is rich, and the characters feel like real people. The radio mechanic is cool as well and adds suspense and tension to the game when you have to tune in to a certain frequency. There's replay value here as well; without spoiling too much, your dialogue choices have far reaching consequences in-game.

If you love games like Life is Strange (story-telling games, that is), you will fall in love with this one too. It's spooky, but I never found myself so scared that I wanted to turn off the game. It has an absolutely stunning art style. The story is wonderful (along with the characters). The ending is nice too! If you play it, one word of advice: Pay attention. And have fun, of course!

On my second play through and even though I know the mystery behind it all I'm still getting goosebumps and shivers down my spine.  The story is engrossing and you really bond with the characters.\nHighly recommened.

This game is like that very tiny and rare piece of chocolate, you have to relax and enjoy every second of it. It is short, but everything about it is so good. Definitely worth savoring more than once.

Emotional adventure. Gave me goosebumps, it spooks you in a really unique way. The art direction is amazing, the characters are lovely, and them multiple-endings. Oh yeah, this game has a looots of secrets. did you know there's a sub-reddit about solving the secrets of this game. This game is amazing.
AMAZING. AMAZING. Ending left my jaw dropping. Definitely going to play again to get all the achievements. Blew my mind. 10/10. AMAZING!!

WOW this game is engaging. I got sucked into it after I played for only 10 minutes.

I'm not going to go into details about the story but In my opinion it's good enough to go into blindely with no knowledge of the game.

The dialogue options are varied and voice acting sounds absolutely amazing.

anyone who has played a Telltale game and like them. I personally recommend you buy this gem!

So I bought the game yesterday (the same day it went out) and before any reviews were released on the internet. But I did saw some cool trailers about that game and I was kinda expecting it. (Even though when it came out yesterday it was a surprise to me haha)

Basically I love this game very much. its pretty original and its very very simple in a fun way. the dialogues are so cool and everything feels so alive. like everything can might happen!
Amazing soundtrack as well.
anyway, after waking up this morning I was not surprise at all seeing very good reviews about that game.

Watch the gameplays and if you like it, you should definitely get it.

Fantastic story, absolutely gorgeous, and beautiful sound design. The atmosephere is great, the pace is well planned and the game feels 100% worth every cent and minute invested. It's not often we get an experience as masterfully crafted as as alot what the movie industry gets to throw oscars at every year. But when we do get something as simple and beautiful as Oxenfree, i get very excited, because it gives me the rare oportunity to say that i wholeheartedly recomend this game.

Amazing game the only issues I could bring up is that there are some bugs with the other characters not moving when they are ment to resulting in freezing the game also there are a few typos in the subtitles and parts where it doesn't match what the audio is saying but aside from that this is a wonderful game and if you are a fan of other narrative driven games such as life is strange or the telltale franchise I highly reccomend giving this game a shot.

reviewText:
Oxenfree is a very entertaining bite-sized game that can be completed in day.  Two days if you take your time.

Overall I enjoyed the character dynamics and mysteries of the island. There are some real moments that make just want to strangle a character or two, but to me that just underscores the quality of the writing. The dialogue is quite clean and natural sounding; however I decided to turn on subtitles as it helps with some of the conversions throughout the game.

There are a few technical issues I noticed though, like a somewhat sticky world when trying to go up stairs. Once, my character got stuck climbing, but then snapped to the top. Once I was with one character, but got the voice of another. Another problem is the choice bubbles are sometime off-screen if you're on an incline.

These issues are not deal breakers, but can certainly break immersion. Those issues aside, I enjoyed the game and definitely recommend it if you're in the market for a cerebral exploration game.
basically if you like telltale and life is strange, youll love this too. that simple.

Oxenfree is a great talk based game that will make you want to contine to play to the end. Right now everything is exelent, I have had no problems with the game. The only problem right now I can think of is the price is too much at £14 for only 5 hours worth of gameplay.\n\nOther than that, if you have money to spend do go and buy this great indie game.

The story, the gameplay and the atmosphere are excellent.

I especially like how the radio works, and how I could use it both to interact with the world and further the story, or jusrt leave it on a song I like and walk around for a while

Also, the art style and soundtrack are both perfect.
Interesting take on tell-tale" style games. And unlike the "tell-tale" game your choices actually feel important."
