Outstanding character-driven story.
If you're an old person trying to recapture your youth and feel like a teenager again, go ahead\n\n♥♥♥♥ Harden fo lyf

Loved this game. Creepy (but not too bad), atmospheric and charming. The dialogue makes you really invested in the characters, and the game mechanics are really neat. The score is fantastic, really sets the tone. This is one of those games that rewards being thorough, so look at everything. And your choice of dialogue actually affects the outcomes, so choose wisely (but be quick).

This one may even be worth another play-through. It's not very long, maybe 3-6 hours. Best played all in on go, so set aside a good amount of time. If you leave the game early, you'll probably end up repeating a few things.

Would recommened this to anyone who like story driven games. Not for the action-loving types. If I had to name something that I think could have been improved on, I would have liked the ending (before the epilogue) to have been a bit more clear/explainy/revelatory. But it's very possible I just missed something the first time through, and the epilogue was great, so I'm not really going to complain.
I absolutely loved this game, the story was beautifully written. I was actually worried for the other characters when things happened to them (dont worry no spoilers ^_^).

This game totally nails a lovely aesthetic and fantastic writing. This isn't a game to play for a challenge: it's all about telling a fascinating story with complex characters. It's difficult to overstate what a pleasure it was just to hear the kids just talking to each other, whether it was about their various points of friction or unraveling the mysteries of what's happening to them.

If you're looking for a game with realistically-written teenage characters, stunningly beautiful backgrounds and art, off-putting and surprising visual effects and glitches, and a chance for branching paths and interesting dialogue, Oxenfree is your game. It's a side-scrolling, almost point-and-click psuedo-puzzle-thriller. I'm not really sure what to label it as, honestly - all I know is that I went into it unsure of what to expect, and wound up being completely drawn in by the visual effects, soundtrack, and beautiful art style. I wasn't quite prepared for the first time the screen went entirely fuzzy, filled with static, and then flipped around a few times. It was amazing.

The story is something that unfolds at a good pace, and character development feels very natural and compelling. There's a lot to be seen and experienced in the game, so it's worth a few playthroughs. I got through my first one around 4 hours or so; I plan on trying at least a few more, just to see what some of the other options do.

I think the only complaint I have about the game lies in the controls; sometimes, they're a little wonky, and it can be hard to maneuver to a specific ledge or ladder or something without taking a few (unnecessary) tries to get it right. I found that playing the game with a controller rather than a mouse helped a lot, in that regard. I was thrown off a little by the speed of the text-box choices at first - you have to choose quickly, in most cases. However, that quickly faded, and choices were easy to make in instances of little time.

All in all, it's a game worth buying, and a game definitely worth playing for yourself rather than just watching!
I loved it that the developers made Ren, one of the characters, a little person and then didn't make a fuss about that. That's how minorities should be represented, I think.
Amazing game, would recommend to anyone thats into these kind of games.

(DISCLAIMER: if you have a story of suicidal thoughts or you have been around a close person who did, this game is NOT for you, as it may trigger them. It deals with very dark themes, you have been adviced.) First of all, I gotta say, this was a pretty strong experience, sure, it may not have the BEST story of all time, and it can be a bit complicated to understand at times, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. This game is about testing your bravery, and wether or not you're willing to sacrifice everything in order to save everyone, even those who you may not like. The voice acting is fantastic and the gameplay is innovative. It's absolutely worth the 20$, and it's definetly a must have.

This game is fantastic. It has a great story with multiple endings.. If you're not into games that mostly depend on choices and want some kind of shooter this isn't the game. However, if you want a truly intelligent game with a creepy feel and great voice cast, I'd pick up Oxenfree. Some sequences are mindblowing and have amazing visuals. Oxenfree also has one of the best soundtracks and I'd recommend picking it up as well.

Definently would recommend if you like games with a Life is Strange sorta gameplay style. Also, love the art style, it's absolutley amazing.

Amazing. I was originally attracted to the artstyle before I really knew what I was getting myself into - and I'm glad I took the chance to play this game. The story is well thought out. At first I was confused as to what was happening, I was always coming up with silly ideas on where the story was actually leading to and I was thrown for a loop" at the end.\n\nHonestly I reccommend this game 100% can't wait to play it again."

Loved this game. Creepy (but not too bad), atmospheric and charming. The dialogue makes you really invested in the characters, and the game mechanics are really neat. The score is fantastic, really sets the tone. This is one of those games that rewards being thorough, so look at everything. And your choice of dialogue actually affects the outcomes, so choose wisely (but be quick).

This one may even be worth another play-through. It's not very long, maybe 3-6 hours. Best played all in on go, so set aside a good amount of time. If you leave the game early, you'll probably end up repeating a few things.

Would recommened this to anyone who like story driven games. Not for the action-loving types. If I had to name something that I think could have been improved on, I would have liked the ending (before the epilogue) to have been a bit more clear/explainy/revelatory. But it's very possible I just missed something the first time through, and the epilogue was great, so I'm not really going to complain.

Oxenfree is really cool; I feel pretty good recommending it to people who enjoy narrative focused games. I should also so, it isn't scary at all - I struggle with even poorly executed, cheesy horror stuff and this game didn't even unsettle me.

The dialogue system is really good - I loved the way conversations flowed. I'm not going to say put it in every game, but it's definitely a novel approach.

I think the most obvious comparison is probably Until Dawn. Oxenfree is subtler and quieter, but I think that's definitely a fair comparison.
The story is good.  The art is fantastic.  Didn't feel too long or too short. I really really like this game.  Good ♥♥♥♥.

I like Oxenfree. The 2D watercolor style art is beautiful and the voice acting is pretty good. The music has that same ambient 80's synth feel as Fez" and "It Follows". The gameplay is pretty basic. Not everyone will be OK with it. I like it. It's mostly dialogue trees and walking with very light puzzles. It's more about the story. I like it though. My only real complaint is that you have to make your dialogue decisions quickly or they will disappear. Seems unnecessary
recommended: and a couple of times I rushed and made choices that I regretted. I would also like it better at $15 for the 5-6 hr campaign. I don't regret the purchase at all and will probably play it again. If you like  interactive story games then I'd pick it up."

reviewText: This game is SO amazing. And I recognized some of the voices, huh. With no unnecessary words. You. Should. Just. Play. This. Game.

Follow my Curator Group  here

Title: Oxenfree
Platform: Windows, Mac, Xbox One
Rating: 13+
Developer: Night School Studio
Publisher: Night School Studio
Price: $20
Release Date: 15/1/16

Oxenfree is a narrative game made by Ex-Telltale Developers. It tells the story of these 5 senior high school teenagers who embark on an annual adventure to an island. Although this time things end up a little different.

The first thing to notice about this game is its graphics and art style. Its 2.5d and while at first glance I didn’t really take note of it, this glamorous style soon grew on me and some sections of the game just looked spectacular. Especially in the darker bits of the story.

You play as Alex, a girl who her personality is being controlled by you, even the past as you will learn through the flashbacks in the game. You can be a jerk to everyone or be everyone’s best friend. Its entirely up to you and this is what I found particularly amazing with the game, while the actual choices on what happens to the main plot isn’t that in depth and different as I could’ve hoped; the actual chemistry between the characters are completely different upon how you speak to them which will in turn change how they speak to you.

The gameplay of this game is mainly walking through the environments while talking to one or some of the querky, stereotypical, but somewhat unique characters. From Ren, your annoying best friend to Clarissa, your ‘‘friend’ who seems to have a grudge on you. Although how you handle it and the consequences is completely up to you. Its also the voice acting that completely seals the deal with these characters. I’ve heard these voices from some old Telltale games but they sounded different, but in a good way. The voices really made me think that these characters were real people and not just artificial intelligence running on a code.

Another part of the gameplay is its dialogue, which is how you talk to the characters. They appear on the screen and you click them as you move along through the environment as the characters talk, although I found that if you interact with something or press a dialogue prompt the person talking will stop. While it isn’t much of a big deal it annoyed me a little as I wanted to finish hearing someone talk but I wanted to say something too. Although most of the time this happened the dialogue was just ‘filler’ and didn’t tie in much with the main story.

Another grope I have with this game is how slow the beginning starts off as. I was getting bored but luckily not so bored to the extent that I was forcing myself through. Although I lost my boredom when I met all the characters and saw all the ‘beef’ between them in the first scene when they are all together. And then when the main plot is finally shown, I was hooked until the very end; even though I felt like my choices of how I were towards the characters were completely different in the end stats as I was being told the conclusion and future of these characters based on how I were towards them. But it didn’t matter much to me as this game is definitely more about the journey than it’s destination.

Other than a somewhat disappointing score as I felt like the music could’ve been done better with some greater soundtracks due to the mystical and grand environments you find. This game is pretty wonderful. It has a great artstyle, story with amazing character development and voice acting, and a great world filled with lore which you will need to play again if you want to uncover everything about Edward’s Island. Even if the main plot choices are a bit lacking, and the dialogue could be interfaced better.

We give this game 4/5.

Oxenfree is just one of those games that just gets it.  It isn't trying to be more than what it is.  If you love story driven games or adventure games this is def for you.  If you still have your doubts check out my video review.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2rUIBwnLttU

Really cool radio thing, pretty scenery, interesting characters and interactions, spooky story for chickens like me. I really like this game. However it still doesn't stand out as an exceptional game for me, can't decide why.
The only negatives I can think of are:
- tedious travelling between locations (fine the first time, and at least there's dialogue to kill time while walking)
- short
- I didn't like Ren (just me, apparently)
Nevertheless I would recommend this game, but buy on sale.

This is probably one of the best horror games I've ever seen.

Oxenfree focuses more on atmosphere and story than actual horror, but believe me, there are still some genuinely scarey bits. It's a really good game if you want to ease into horror games; it's almost like a movie with a choose your own adventure twist. It's also a really neat game for people who can't play video games really well or don't want to fight in their games. Fighting seems to be a big thing in most horror games, and although this isn't the first game to do that, it's still a realitively fresh thing.

The story is actually pretty creative, although does carry a few tired tropes like  that Alex's brother is dead and she (and Clarisse) have to deal with it along with the spooky happenings  but it's not too distracting or even that bad. Most of the tropes are written so well I can't really say it's a bad thing, only that it's not original. Some things in the story seem a little dated, but again, it's not too distracting. It's a mostly timeless game yet it can take place in a pretty small span of years, which is hard to do. They take full advantage of this  by using smart phones to take pictures of the spooky spots and showing them in a polariod picture with the ghost in the background of the photo . It's not only an interesting disign, but also has a small role in world building.

The art is amazing. The backgrounds and sets: absolutely sets the mood. The little photos that are taken from time to time have a nice aesthetic feel to it. The character animations are wonderful: shifting, moving their hands, and walking realistically and showing emotion through body language rather than facial expressions.

One major problem I had with this game is the amount of talking, which is all written and voice acted perfectly, but can be pretty long and drawn out. If you're like me and are pretty distractable and/or get restless just sitting and reading/listening or moving from point A to point B without much action, you'll need to be in the right mood to play it. If lots of dialogue is you're thing, go for it. Otherwise, find another game that's more simulating.

A small tip for the above issue: if things get too boring or slow, pause and walk around a bit, eat, splash water on your face, whatever. Just do things to break up the amount of time you're just sitting and reading/listening.

Fully enjoyed the whole game! Something new on the gameplay where it felt like a real life situation like how the characters talk to each other and we had to choose what we should respond in a short period of time to cut in a conversation. haha very fascinating! Love how the storyline is also unpredictable. Definitely well put together.

One thing I noticed off the bat was that the voice acting is pretty bad. Little nit picky things that annoy me in this game is that people sigh way to much and no one sounds genuine, like the voice actors are trying to force emotions and they come out weird.\n\nI would only recommend this game when/if it goes on sale.

Oxenfree is an emotionally charged game that cleverly takes advantage of player-choice mechanics.

There's much to be said about the positives of this game: whimsical graphics, an eerily beautiful soundtrack, well-defined characters with fantastic performances by their voice actors. The story follows Alex in such a way to reveal important information about her and her situation without spelling it out for the player, and the player gets to know Jonas in the same way that Alex does. The game isn't *terrifying*, but I admit I was startled quite a few times while playing -- enough to keep me on my toes, but not too much to make me anxious about playing.

Things I didn't like about the game? Well, there's not much to dislike, to be honest. I guess the speed at which the characters walk and climb objects is annoying, but a lot of the time, the dialogue fills in that space, and makes it less boring. The mechanics of the radio aren't super fun, either. It's an essential portion of the game, yet I had issues with the radio closing out when I was turning the dial, and making me repeat sequences of tunings over again. This, in itself, would be a harmless glitch if it didn't take forever to change the channel on the radio. It made discovering the anomalies" disinteresting to me since it just took so long to walk to the rocks and then tune the radio to the right station. But maybe I'm just too impatient.

I've never particularly been a fan of the idea that the playtime or amount of content in a game should be the sole arbiter of its value. Oxenfree isn't an incredibly long experience, but it's one of spectacular quality, and in every way worth the money. The Telltale tenure of the game developers really shines through in the writing, the storytelling, and the atmosphere. The characters are rich and nuanced, the plot is well-paced and intriguing, the dialogue (with a few minor exceptions) is well-written and genuine, and the casting and voice acting are phenomenal.\n\nNight School Studio really managed to hit their first release out of the park, and I'm certainly looking forward to their future offerings.

Oxenfree is a very entertaining bite-sized game that can be completed in day.  Two days if you take your time.

Overall I enjoyed the character dynamics and mysteries of the island. There are some real moments that make just want to strangle a character or two, but to me that just underscores the quality of the writing. The dialogue is quite clean and natural sounding; however I decided to turn on subtitles as it helps with some of the conversions throughout the game.

There are a few technical issues I noticed though, like a somewhat sticky world when trying to go up stairs. Once, my character got stuck climbing, but then snapped to the top. Once I was with one character, but got the voice of another. Another problem is the choice bubbles are sometime off-screen if you're on an incline.

These issues are not deal breakers, but can certainly break immersion. Those issues aside, I enjoyed the game and definitely recommend it if you're in the market for a cerebral exploration game.

I'm having a hard time finding the words to describe the experience I had with this game. For a few hours I was totally immersed in Alex's life and felt emotions as if I was in her shoes, navigating my way through this otherworldly adventure. The voice acting comes off as authentic, and the art style manages to be simultaneously beautiful and demonic. Overall, an intriguing story told in a way that you probably have not experienced before. Once is enough for me, but I am glad to have taken the chance on this one.
Amazing game overall.

This may be a positive recommendation, but take it with a MASSIVE grain of salt. Like, a salt-rock. Seriously. Oxenfree is... Ambitious. This is one of the few positive things I can honestly say for it.

It has an interesting art style that, unfortunately, is hard to focus on given the extreme distance of the camera. Some finer details would have been nice, or zooming in on characters talking during appropriately important moments. The scenery is occasionally vibrant, but given that most of it is misty and vague, it leaves something to be desired. Oh, and the character animations were awkward as all get out.

The music was interesting, and I loved fiddling with the radio and finding bizarre tunes or clips straight out of history, but after a while it was repetitious and not a single piece really gripped me or kept me excited. The overall tone of the game was far too muted for far too long, and the rare moments of excitement, which were decently highlighted with cool effects both visual and auditory, did not make up for the periods of downtime (in a relatively short game I might add!).

It was fairly tedious to navigate the map, with no option to quickly travel from one important location to another once you'd discovered it and done a key thing there. I suppose that would have made the experience even thinner, but the rigors of zig-zagging in 2.5D up and down some really uninspired pathing kind of took its toll when the conversations dwindled away.

The writing itself felt... empty at times. It wasn't that it was poor, per se, or that there weren't interesting elements. Just that, despite the information overload of letters and clues, or conversations and experiences, I never felt particularly attached to the island or the characters. It was a bit like going to a museum with strangers. Strangers who were kind of irritating, more often than not. Some of the moments were fairly genuine, and I liked being a smart aleck, and warming up to whoever I could, but it still felt... underdeveloped.

Then, there's the voice acting. Alex, the main character, was fairly well done! But I think the other characters were a little lacking overall. The recordings were all pretty loud, and felt isolated from their setting. While the idea of being able to walk and talk is nice, and interrupting characters feels a touch more natural than how some games handle the intricacies of conversation, it just fell as flat as pretty much everything else in the game.

Oh, and the animations again added a kind dissonance, where characters would be talking to you from a pretty far distance if you didn't follow them around or wanted to look at something else while keeping track of the conversation thread. I can understand speaking across a room, but maybe recognize and pause for a moment when they decide to walk out the door on me? Or don't have them stray too far. Once, I even had a character insist I do a certain action while standing in the complete wrong spot and even bugging it out for me. I couldn't move, once I chose to interact with the thing, and she didn't arrive and join me to finish it. I had to restart from entering that particular screen (another saving grace might have been the ability to manually save).

All in all, I really wanted more from this. It's got hooks. It's got promise. But it doesn't really deliver. I still think it's worth a purchase, and I don't really regret the experience, but it does frustrate me. Keep your expectations in check, and it will probably satisfy you.

reviewText:
This game is different than any other choice-based game I've played. It felt really natural sometimes. Usually I'm thinking what would the right choice for this conversation be, but in here... it felt like I was really there. Talking to my teenage friends and wanted to say what I wanted to say.
Storyline in overall is great, very supernatural and interesting. I could really feel the emotions of the characters in the game, including the main character Alex.
With no spoilers the puzzles in this game can be challenging, but also very easy to understand.

I would really jump in again and go a different way to tell the story.

I stayed away from the trailers which I'm glad I did, and you should too. This game has the emotional core of Life is Strange and a similar story structure of Until Dawn. The result is a delightfully non-threatening cosmic horror adventure game. Few jumpscares await you. It is visually stunning and I adore the watercolour art style. It helps to build the world of Edwards Island: desolate albeit rich in beauty and mystery, which shines even in its supposedly mundane moments. The dialogues grab you early on and continues to shine in many key parts of this branching story, especially in moments when you least expect it. And of course, the sound design, soundtrack and voice acting is very important to this game, and they delivered perfectly. An absolute treat for both the ears and the eyes, and anyone with an unhealthy obsession with triangles. However, the story is not mind-blowing, but the writing is nonetheless decent in delivering its premise, though it could be paced better. It's a shame it is a short game but I enjoyed it thoroughly.\n\nEDIT: I take back about what I said about the story. It can be brilliant if you 'play it right' and if you listen to the characters, even those you do not like.
Although it's only ~3.5 hours long, it is a pretty nice experience. Kudos to the voice actors and writers.
Help someone. Oxenfree isn't working for my computer. There is a sound ,but the the screen won't display on the screen.\n\nEven though I haven't played it, I can tell that I will LOVE this game.

Okay, I just finished the game so here is my opinion: Oxenfree has a really nice art and a good story.
If you are into games that are all about the roleplaying than that's your game.
Expect no action, battles nor exploration. It has none of those.
But still is some money that I found worth spending.
And I do think you should give it a shot too!
P.s.: The game crashes in transitions and that's kinda annoying... Not I want to kill myself" annoying but "damn fly" annoying."

Not perfect, there are a few hiccups in gameplay and it didn't quite tap all of the potential it's premise set up.

But still this is a great experience regardless, this game has charming visuals, witty writing, charming characters helped by really good voice acting, great sound design and music, and a beautiful/chilling atmosphere. Oxenfree it is absolutely what I love in a game, great atmosphere, it is an EXPERIENCE, you are taken on a journey. THIS is art.

The game is a bit like Life is Strange in tone if it had more beleivable characters and much, MUCH better voice acting. Speaking of voice acting, the conversation system this game has is one of the best I've seen, you chime in during another characters dialogue in response to something they're saying. You can just ignore the conversation though and walk around doing whatever, even if they're talking right to you, you can let it hang. It makes the dialogue feel much more organic.

Again, the game slows down a bit at the ending, not to the degree Life is Strange did, the ending is still fairly strong, but the best parts are definitely when the whole crew is together early game having those organic conversations you chime in on and direct. Truth or Slap, the game at the beginning, was my favorite part.

For a debut title they did a very good job, this charming title was delivered very well and I can't wait to see more games from this publisher in the future.
yeah, it was really good

But one better than Sword and Sworcery, the cast actually feel like living people, not just side characters in your more important hero story. I had fairly complex feelings about every person on that island, which is a very rare feeling in most games.

I'm nearing the end of the game as I write this review. Like many other reviewers, I know this is a stellar game from what it's done so far, not needing to know what happens next to form a solid opinion. And, like them, I'd imagine, I'm incredibly excited to find out what ultimately happens to these people I've come to know so intimately as I round out my time on Edward's Island.

This game is incredibly story rich, sometimes it takes a little time to wrap your head around things that just happened but it does make sense in the end, kinda. I enjoyed the teen drama, even if it felt a little forced, and I enjoyed each characters personality. The art and overall scenes were amazing and the voices, pure brilliance. The only negative thing I could say about this game is that it felt very limited in where you could go and what you can do, for example choosing someone to go with you, or even having conversations with them. You couldn't initiate them or choose when to talk, you were prompted. Having save slots/files would be welcomed warmly here too, I really dont feel like going through the whole game again just to unlock a few achievments. For what it's worth I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys a bit of a read and likes to choose their own path and their relationships with others. I hope to see more of these games later on, and maybe a dlc wouldn't be too bad either.

Loved this game. Creepy (but not too bad), atmospheric and charming. The dialogue makes you really invested in the characters, and the game mechanics are really neat. The score is fantastic, really sets the tone. This is one of those games that rewards being thorough, so look at everything. And your choice of dialogue actually affects the outcomes, so choose wisely (but be quick).

This one may even be worth another play-through. It's not very long, maybe 3-6 hours. Best played all in on go, so set aside a good amount of time. If you leave the game early, you'll probably end up repeating a few things.

Would recommened this to anyone who like story driven games. Not for the action-loving types. If I had to name something that I think could have been improved on, I would have liked the ending (before the epilogue) to have been a bit more clear/explainy/revelatory. But it's very possible I just missed something the first time through, and the epilogue was great, so I'm not really going to complain.

Oxenfree is really cool; I feel pretty good recommending it to people who enjoy narrative focused games. I should also so, it isn't scary at all - I struggle with even poorly executed, cheesy horror stuff and this game didn't even unsettle me.

The dialogue system is really good - I loved the way conversations flowed. I'm not going to say put it in every game, but it's definitely a novel approach.

I think the most obvious comparison is probably Until Dawn. Oxenfree is subtler and quieter, but I think that's definitely a fair comparison.

I absolutely love this game. The graphics, both design and texture, are beautiful and the mode of gameplay is amazing.  It's a game for people who like the development of a story. A game for people who want to flesh out the characters and the plot.  I also really like the voice acting and overall the audio of the game is wonderfully done. My only complaint is there are one or two areas where the players move a little bit wonky - but who knows if it the game or my system.

Oxenfree is pretty much what I'd imagine the creators of the Twilight Zone would make if they were modern day game devs. A seemingly normal situation, a sense of creepiness that builds wonderfully as the game progresses, and endings in which you will always be trapped in this version of the twilight zone.

It's got a few little pests in the gameplay area. While the 3D characters in a mostly 2D space can look very charming, there are some areas where it gets hard to move around as you're not sure if the game wants you to go up or sideways. Sometimes the characters have uncomfortably long gaps between their lines, breaking up the immersion a bit. And some of the dialogue prompts fade so quickly that they're gone before you've read all the choices. But these are minor annoyances. The game itself has a solid story that really sucks you in and makes up for any of the above.

I've got some issues with the ending(s), but nevertheless, it's got plenty of replay value. It seems like you could get a whole lot of new and different dialogue by making different choices. Personally, I recommend it, and am looking forward to playing it again.

I finished my first playthrough last night. I really love this game! The characters are all likeable and the dialogue isn't a total train wreck of what adults think kids these days must talk like. The game has a very strong aesthetic and the characters flow seamlessly in the 2D painted environments. Oh, and the story's good too.

Wonderful game! I really loved the creepy/eerie atmosphere of the game; I love ghost stories so it was a blast for me!\nThe game has a re-occuring bug (a character gets 'stuck') that made me restart the game a few time but it doesn't really impact the enjoyability (and it will probably be fixed in a future patch).\nI totally recommend it!
Very atmospheric and creepy. Great character development and what teen movies SHOULD be. There is a section of the game that glitches really bad, but hopefully there will be a patch for it soon.
Really nice! Everything in it is beautiful! And you get to feel for the characters. It makes me want to evaluate almost everything I say from here on out. What you say makes in impact.

Cool game. Great story with brilliant voice acting.

My gripes are two:

1. The text bubbles are white font with light green backgrounds - making them very hard to read. In situations where you sometimes have to react quickly, this is a huge annoyance which shouldn't even be a problem. Black font would have fixed this; no idea why they chose to make the text white.

2. This one may just be me, but I would have appreciated a zoom feature. Being able to get a close up of the characters and backgrounds would be a nice feature. The wide shots are great for establishing the scenery, but I just want to zoom in every once in awhile to get a closer look.

Other than those two things, this is a superb game. A bit short with only a 4-hour playtime, but that's probably for the best - keeps the narrative tight and without needless fetch-quests and item hunts.

Definitely recommend this to anyone who likes story and dialogue heavy games.

This game was absolutely beautiful and is filled with many mysteries that'll keep you interested in the game as you play. Definitely a game worth buying during a sale, but the $20.00 price tag is a little high if you ask me.\n\n8/10

hmmm I was entertained. But I expected too much out of the game. And spent too much. Definitly too pricy for how good and how long the game is. I only spent as many hours as i did cuz i left it open while i took a nap. Plus theres walking. Some of which is there to have something to do while the characters talk but it got tedious at times. I hated climbing the most. I guess overall I just overestimated the game. But in the end I guess id still call it good.\n\nI reccomend it when they lower the price a bunch.

This game makes me feel like I'm playing a video game again. An actual solid, well thought out, immersive, greatly detailed video game. The idea of the core gameplay itself is refreshing and flatout brilliant in its execution. Memorable characters with excellent voice actors that get lost in the world of their roles (always a plus), great level design, solid and easy to understand gameplay mechanics, an atmosphere that draws me in, an amazing soundtrack, and a storyline that keeps me guessing and wanting to continue on my journey - all of these aspects has probably put this game into my top 10 games of all time. Maybe even my top 5!

Seriously, for such a simple game, yet with such a complex and brilliant presentation, it EASILY competes with many games that have been developed by big name developers and publishers out there. It's masterful is what it is! Well, maybe not masterful. There's this latency issue where the game slows down and lags for some odd reason. Whether this is an optimization error or what, I have no idea. Thankfully, it doesn't happen too often and it might be just an issue on my end. But that's not my main gripe.

My main gripe is the multi-choice character dialogue. When I choose a statement the character says something that isn't what I was expecting. As I result I keep reloading the scenes just to choose the one I intended. It has the BioWare thing going on. But that's minor compared to the true brilliance of this game; brilliance that I am about to reveal to you.

Unlike BioWare and their games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age (or any game with multiple choice dialogue), in Oxenfree, when you're in a conversation, your response can just be... nothing... NOTHING. ABSOLUTELY NOTHING! YES! THANK YOU, OXENFREE! For once when characters are bickering with each other I can just stay quiet and reserve my responses! I don't have to choose an option! I don't have to force my character's input on others! And that's why I love this game so much! My overall involvment, or lack there of, feels so much more real and engaging for me when I can just listen a conversation out and add my input in when it is necessary! Absolutely GENIUS!!!

A big ol' 10/10, would buy another copy and give to a friend!

Oxenfree is pure joy.

I haven't had such an interesting journey in a very long time. Everything, from the aesthetics, to the acting, to the story, is positively perfect.

I know there will be detractors; there always is. But Oxenfree set out to do one thing, and one thing only: It set out to create a modest yet masterful thriller adventure, with killer unique aesthetics, good characters and a legitimately effective atmosphere.

It did all that and so much more.

My one and only complaint is that I didn't have more of it. I rarely feel this; I'm okay with games on the shorter end of the spectrum -- one or two hour games are fine by me, and Oxenfree lasted me for about 7 hours -- but this atmosphere and context was so well done that I feel the writer could have come up with a couple more roundabouts particularly toward the middle of the story. I realize more lines of dialogue to record means more money that must be used to pay the actors and I absolutely don't hold it against Night School Studio.

Ultimately, it was the right choice to keep it short and simple, as opposed to overambitious and suffering from feature creep.

I enjoyed my time with Oxenfree thoroughly and I can't wait to jump back in and see what else can happen in the game's dynamic ending. If you like thrillers, the supernatural, good aesthetics, or just basically good stuff in general, I think you owe it to yourself to grab this right now.
Perfect mix of story and puzzle. Believeable and well done voice acting that gives it a great atmosphere.
Very engrossing, atmospheric indie adventure game. Reminds me of the sort of pared down minimalist horror films that have become popular in the last few years ( e.g. It Follows).

Wow, really just wow. Between the great voice acting, creative story, and relatable characters, Oxenfree is a real gem, worthy of a few playthroughs.

The art style is quite nice, reminiscent of older animated movies and television shows from the late 90's and early 2000's. Backgrounds have a painted, rich feeling that really makes the map lovely to explore. The characters art is simple, but unique, drawing an image for the character, but not setting them into an archetype. This game is really wonderful to look at. The antagonist spirits appear as shadows, punctuated with partial red outline that gives them a certain alien feeling of wrongness. Overall the art sets the feeling of the game wonderfully and helps to draw in the player right off the bat.

The story and dialog are really inspired and very well done. At no point do the characters really become stereotypes, although a few characters aren't completely fleshed out, by the end. Exposition is carried out tastefully and naturally. Natural is actually a very good word for describing the majority of the dialog in the game, it feels normal, the conversations feel like conversations that real teenagers would have. Lately, some games with characters around this age have tried to shoehorn in pop culture references that often feel contrived and awkward. Oxenfree doesn't try this, opting to instead have the characters interact like normal people. Bolstered by some fantastic voice acting, the script is wonderful. The story is involving and smart, tying the characters together and moving forward at a good pace. Combined with optional collectibles scattered around the map, the story really builds the history of the island and surrounding towns into something memorable.

In terms of gameplay and puzzles, Oxenfree plays it simple and safe. Controls are basic, although traversing the map can get a little slow. The scenery is usually attractive enough to make the jogs between areas at worst acceptable, and at best a joy. The game is verging on being a walking simulator, with all of the puzzles being very simply moving the mouse left or right. Different dialog options and endings make the game's replayability high, along with finding all of the collectibles that aren't required, but help to complete the world.

The score for the game is fantastic, matching the mood perfectly, the soundtrack for this game goes up there with Transistor and Bastion as some of my favorite videogame music.

Without gathering collectibles, the game will take around 2-4 hours to complete for one playthrough, with another hour or so for gathering the collectibles. The game, in my opinion, deserves at least 2 full playthroughs, as there are many different possible endings and choices that can be made.

Tl;dr:

Pros:
-gorgeous art
-great voice acting
-wonderful story and dialog
-good atmosphere
-beautiful music

Cons:
-very simple puzzles
-slow movement makes for a little slogging

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Superbrothers:Swords and Sworcery and Kentucky Route Zero.

reviewText: hmmm I was entertained. But I expected too much out of the game. And spent too much. Definitly too pricy for how good and how long the game is. I only spent as many hours as i did cuz i left it open while i took a nap. Plus theres walking. Some of which is there to have something to do while the characters talk but it got tedious at times. This game makes me feel like I'm playing a video game again. An actual solid, well thought out, immersive, greatly detailed video game. The idea of the core gameplay itself is refreshing and flatout brilliant in its execution. Memorable characters with excellent voice actors that get lost in the world of their roles (always a plus), great level design, solid and easy to understand gameplay mechanics, an atmosphere that draws me in, an amazing soundtrack, and a storyline that keeps me guessing and wanting to continue on my journey - all of these aspects has probably put this game into my top 10 games of all time. Maybe even my top 5!

Seriously, for such a simple game, yet with such a complex and brilliant presentation, it EASILY competes with many games that have been developed by big name developers and publishers out there. It's masterful is what it is! Well, maybe not masterful. There's this latency issue where the game slows down and lags for some odd reason. Whether this is an optimization error or what, I have no idea. Thankfully, it doesn't happen too often and it might be just an issue on my end. But that's not my main gripe.

My main gripe is the multi-choice character dialogue. When I choose a statement the character says something that isn't what I was expecting. As I result I keep reloading the scenes just to choose the one I intended. It has the BioWare thing going on. But that's minor compared to the true brilliance of this game; brilliance that I am about to reveal to you.

Unlike BioWare and their games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age (or any game with multiple choice dialogue), in Oxenfree, when you're in a conversation, your response can just be... nothing... NOTHING. ABSOLUTELY NOTHING! YES! THANK YOU, OXENFREE! For once when characters are bickering with each other I can just stay quiet and reserve my responses! I don't have to choose an option! I don't have to force my character's input on others! And that's why I love this game so much! My overall involvment, or lack there of, feels so much more real and engaging for me when I can just listen a conversation out and add my input in when it is necessary! Absolutely GENIUS!!!

A big ol' 10/10, would buy another copy and give to a friend!

Great decision-based game with an interesting story! Feels almost like the Life is Strange of early 2016, which isn't a bad thing that it has a similar style in terms of gameplay, because the way it executes it is unique and fun. Definently would recommend if you like games with a Life is Strange sorta gameplay style. Also, love the art style, it's absolutley amazing.

Oxenfree is one of those games i just couldnt put down until i had finished it al!! I wanted to know more about where the story was going, i wanted to hear the charaters interact more and above all, i wanted to see just what the hell was going on with this island! The only con for me was that at times i felt like i had no time to read+think about my responce before the speechbubbles faded out,so it would have been good to have an extra 5 seconds on occasion.

Lovely interactive story with great atmosphere.

Oxenfree manages to keep the player engaged with minimal game mechanics, thanks to it's dialogue (which makes up large amount of the gameplay), likeable and fleshed-out characters and their relationships - which may change, depending on how conversations go - as well as suspenseful island mystery adventure. Never once does the game rely on gore or jump scares, yet the danger and creepiness are very much tangible throughout the story.

The art style is a beautiful breath of fresh air and perfectly captures the athmosphere of the progressing night.

As the second major game mechanic, the radio brings the island to life, as both prerecorded tour guides explaining its history and eerie distortions can be found by tuning into the right frequencies at the right places - a detail that makes the place feel like it actually has a past, and a questionable one at that.

With 4 hours of playtime for completing the story once the game is a bit on the short side, but the dialogue driven, flexible nature of it offers great replayability.

Oxenfree tells an unconventional story about loss and friendship, as seen through the eyes of a teenager and her group of unsuspecting friends. It starts out innocently enough, on a boat headed to an isolated island for an overnight party. However, once things start to get weird, they get satisfyingly really weird, and the supernatural events quickly become engrossing. Rewinds, time loops, possessions, visions; all are handled in a fascinating way.

The overall smooth execution make this a must-play title for players who enjoy narrative-rich experiences without the fuss of complex interactions. Though it is sometimes unclear what consequences your choices will have, the game constantly progresses in a pleasant, steady rhythm.

While it looks positively great, its sound production in particular is brilliantly beyond anything else in its category. The voice actors all do a splendid job and render each character unconditionally believable, down to every stutter or natural hesitation. All of this is heightened by a haunting score and chilling sound effects.

My only gripe with the game is that its text options disappear all too quickly. Considering they're the bulk of your interactions in the world, it's pretty upsetting. If you select a choice too soon, you'll often interrupt someone, but not always. If you don't act fast enough, you will forever lose your opportunity to engage in that moment. This inconsistency initially sparked strong disappointment, but it becomes manageable once you get used to it. Also worth nothing that there is no wrong answer, and choosing not to say anything is also a valid option.

There is not much in terms of puzzles to solve. Tuning into the right radio frequency is always just a guess, and although it feels very innovative at first it loses a bit of its charm along the way. I wish there was something more logical to it, instead of just scanning the band left and right until something happens.

Oxenfree offers some collectibles, of which anomalies appear entirely pointless, whereas lost letters provide interesting context and enrich the narrative. I'm never a fan of those and wish these elements had been delivered in a more integral manner. A useful map keeps track of your current objective, or rather destination, and unless the player intends to collect stuff there's never any need to stray from the main linear path.

Its disquieting ending fits the theme almost too perfectly. It left me feeling slightly depressed, as most thorough introspective stories tend to do temporarily. It is positively short, in that it doesn't overstay its welcome. I am satisfied with a single playthrough but the game does offer multiple ending variations, which I was curious enough to look up on the web. If this was a book I'd read it. If this was a movie or TV series I'd watch it.

Loading this game up, and pressing start begins a journey that you can't comprehend with a single playthrough.

As an artist I want to begin with the visual beauty of this game. It's gorgeous. Every part of the island is unique and haunting while fitting the comicbook style visuals. Or should I say the 90s Saturday morning cartoon style-of which you recorded on a single vhs too many times and the magnetic strip started wearing out around the edges... It all meshes and adds to the atmosphere. It's eerie and scary without jumpscares and loud sounds.

Which rolls us into the audio; being the true genius of Oxenfree. I don't know much about the time period the radio tunes us in to, but the clips that were chosen, from old wailing poka to bugs bunny, are all set to make you feel off, to add to the atmosphere you're wandering through. The dialogue, and the warped hollow sounds of the spirits, and the whispers caught over the airwaves, are all perfect.

I can't exactly talk about dialogue without getting into gameplay. Because participating in conversations is one of the major points of gameplay. Like a Bioware or Tell Tale game you have multiple things you can say in conversations. You learn different things about the characters in each playthrough, because you don't have the time to stick around and keep chatting. You effect your relationships with your friends with rarely the chance to truly make amends. And I wont mention how your choices actually effect the ending. Because they do. And there's some mind melting endings you can dredge up. The other major point of gameplay is the radio. Using a Steam controller, I found the radio puzzles simple to solve, but in a third playthrough I found that solving them too fast cut off dialogue I hadn't heard. Moving around the map doesn't take too much time, the only part of the map I hate traversing is climbing up and down the radio tower... And there's only been one glitch I've encountered so far, and it's not gamebreaking.

The plot is deep. And while I say a couple endings are mind melting, the adventure you go on is what really makes Oxenfree spectacular. At every step there's character interaction, something to learn about the island, or the spirits toying with you. There has been so much detail and care put into the world that half way through your frist run you think you're piecing together what really happened, only to realize that while the spirits do have a story, they aren't the problem.

Oxenfree has a lot to offer, if you don't want to give the masterminds behind this beautiful game the twenty bucks they earned, you can wait for a sale. I wont judge. But aside from a few minor glitches that'll probly get fixed, and a lackluster collectathon I can't reccomend this game enough.

Oxenfree is a 2D, 4 hour long, story-driven mystery/thriller/supernatural adventure game with horror elements.

Pros:
- Great visuals and art style
- Fantastic voice acting
- Likable characters
- Well written original story and dialogue
- Story can get very unpredictable
- Interesting game mechanic (Radio)
- Multiple endings
- Relationships with characters can be drastically different depending on your choices
- Good amount of variation with choices
- Conversations between you and other characters can be very fluid and realistic
- Replayability
- Spooky

Cons:
- You'll have to interrupt ongoing dialogue a lot before your dialogue tree timer runs out
- Endings are similar
- Characters don't act very realistically to certain events (Easily brushing off horrifying events)
- If you want to replay a certain choice, you're gonna have to start from the beginning.
- Stinger

Overall:
- The twists and turns, story and characters kept me hooked. However, the similarities between each ending leave a lot to be desired. But if you want, you could replay it to collect and find whatever secrets you missed along with choosing dfferent ways to interact with other characters and choosing different characters to hang around"with
date: which can lead to different results.\n- I loved it
recommended: and by the end of the short journey... I just wanted more."

reviewText:
Started playing and could not stop until I had completed the story, truly gripping. With fascinating dialogue, beautiful art and a very immersive world, this is a game you have got to play. The eerie nature of this game makes it unique, the characters are all likeable bar one or two predictiable developments, however these do not down grade this game. A game similiar to telltale games, although with this you really do feel like you are a character and that your decisions affect the end game. This becomes apparent on a second, third or fourth playthrough.

Believe me, as soon as I completed my first run through, I wanted to immediately start again. There is so much to this game you cannot not play more than once.

For sure, Oxenfree is a game of the year contender already. It is a real diamond. So go and buy this and discover the mystery that lurks in the air and over the radios.
If you're an old person trying to recapture your youth and feel like a teenager again, go ahead\n\n♥♥♥♥ Harden fo lyf

Loved this game. Creepy (but not too bad), atmospheric and charming. The dialogue makes you really invested in the characters, and the game mechanics are really neat. The score is fantastic, really sets the tone. This is one of those games that rewards being thorough, so look at everything. And your choice of dialogue actually affects the outcomes, so choose wisely (but be quick).

This one may even be worth another play-through. It's not very long, maybe 3-6 hours. Best played all in on go, so set aside a good amount of time. If you leave the game early, you'll probably end up repeating a few things.

Would recommened this to anyone who like story driven games. Not for the action-loving types. If I had to name something that I think could have been improved on, I would have liked the ending (before the epilogue) to have been a bit more clear/explainy/revelatory. But it's very possible I just missed something the first time through, and the epilogue was great, so I'm not really going to complain.

Oxenfree is really cool; I feel pretty good recommending it to people who enjoy narrative focused games. I should also so, it isn't scary at all - I struggle with even poorly executed, cheesy horror stuff and this game didn't even unsettle me.

The dialogue system is really good - I loved the way conversations flowed. I'm not going to say put it in every game, but it's definitely a novel approach.

I think the most obvious comparison is probably Until Dawn. Oxenfree is subtler and quieter, but I think that's definitely a fair comparison.

I absolutely love this game. The graphics, both design and texture, are beautiful and the mode of gameplay is amazing.  It's a game for people who like the development of a story. A game for people who want to flesh out the characters and the plot.  I also really like the voice acting and overall the audio of the game is wonderfully done. My only complaint is there are one or two areas where the players move a little bit wonky - but who knows if it the game or my system.

Oxenfree possesses all the wistful teenage nostalgia of Life Is Strange, but with better writing.

Its supernatural story evokes the feeling of telling ghost stories around a campfire with your friends when you were seventeen. And I would want those friends to be these guys.

If you're into the idea of vollying witty banter back and forth while exploring a Scooby-Doo mystery in an 80's teen flick aesthetic, Oxenfree will totally deliver on that.
I loved it that the developers made Ren, one of the characters, a little person and then didn't make a fuss about that. That's how minorities should be represented, I think.
Amazing game, would recommend to anyone thats into these kind of games.

This game is absolutely nuts, in the most amazing way. It meshes the aesthetic of Life is Strange with the overarching unease and mood of Over the Garden Wall, with a tinge of Until Dawn to create a simple, but thoroughly enjoyable and visually beautiful game. The spooky moments tie in really excellently into the mechanics of the game, and don't rely on jump scares or gore to be frightening, making it enjoyable for fans of the horror genre while also not being too intense for the more gentle-hearted. What I really enjoy, however, is the way the dialogue is handled--a lot of people complain that it goes too fast to click sometimes, but to me that makes it seem more natural--you don't have time to deeply contemplate your dialogue choices, so you just have to say something quick and hope it's good, just like talking to real people.\nIf you're a fan of narrative games and are looking for a new game that won't take too much of your time, I cannot reccommend this enough. It has a lot of heart.

(DISCLAIMER: if you have a story of suicidal thoughts or you have been around a close person who did, this game is NOT for you, as it may trigger them. It deals with very dark themes, you have been adviced.) First of all, I gotta say, this was a pretty strong experience, sure, it may not have the BEST story of all time, and it can be a bit complicated to understand at times, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. This game is about testing your bravery, and wether or not you're willing to sacrifice everything in order to save everyone, even those who you may not like. The voice acting is fantastic and the gameplay is innovative. It's absolutely worth the 20$, and it's definetly a must have.
great game
I find this game really great but I can't help but to feel there's more to this game and it's driving me crazy.

Really cool radio thing, pretty scenery, interesting characters and interactions, spooky story for chickens like me. I really like this game. However it still doesn't stand out as an exceptional game for me, can't decide why.
The only negatives I can think of are:
- tedious travelling between locations (fine the first time, and at least there's dialogue to kill time while walking)
- short
- I didn't like Ren (just me, apparently)
Nevertheless I would recommend this game, but buy on sale.

This is probably one of the best horror games I've ever seen.

Oxenfree focuses more on atmosphere and story than actual horror, but believe me, there are still some genuinely scarey bits. It's a really good game if you want to ease into horror games; it's almost like a movie with a choose your own adventure twist. It's also a really neat game for people who can't play video games really well or don't want to fight in their games. Fighting seems to be a big thing in most horror games, and although this isn't the first game to do that, it's still a realitively fresh thing.

The story is actually pretty creative, although does carry a few tired tropes like  that Alex's brother is dead and she (and Clarisse) have to deal with it along with the spooky happenings  but it's not too distracting or even that bad. Most of the tropes are written so well I can't really say it's a bad thing, only that it's not original. Some things in the story seem a little dated, but again, it's not too distracting. It's a mostly timeless game yet it can take place in a pretty small span of years, which is hard to do. They take full advantage of this  by using smart phones to take pictures of the spooky spots and showing them in a polariod picture with the ghost in the background of the photo . It's not only an interesting disign, but also has a small role in world building.

The art is amazing. The backgrounds and sets: absolutely sets the mood. The little photos that are taken from time to time have a nice aesthetic feel to it. The character animations are wonderful: shifting, moving their hands, and walking realistically and showing emotion through body language rather than facial expressions.

One major problem I had with this game is the amount of talking, which is all written and voice acted perfectly, but can be pretty long and drawn out. If you're like me and are pretty distractable and/or get restless just sitting and reading/listening or moving from point A to point B without much action, you'll need to be in the right mood to play it. If lots of dialogue is you're thing, go for it. Otherwise, find another game that's more simulating.

A small tip for the above issue: if things get too boring or slow, pause and walk around a bit, eat, splash water on your face, whatever. Just do things to break up the amount of time you're just sitting and reading/listening.

Fully enjoyed the whole game! Something new on the gameplay where it felt like a real life situation like how the characters talk to each other and we had to choose what we should respond in a short period of time to cut in a conversation. haha very fascinating! Love how the storyline is also unpredictable. Definitely well put together.

One thing I noticed off the bat was that the voice acting is pretty bad. Little nit picky things that annoy me in this game is that people sigh way to much and no one sounds genuine, like the voice actors are trying to force emotions and they come out weird.\n\nI would only recommend this game when/if it goes on sale.

Oxenfree is an emotionally charged game that cleverly takes advantage of player-choice mechanics.

There's much to be said about the positives of this game: whimsical graphics, an eerily beautiful soundtrack, well-defined characters with fantastic performances by their voice actors. The story follows Alex in such a way to reveal important information about her and her situation without spelling it out for the player, and the player gets to know Jonas in the same way that Alex does. The game isn't *terrifying*, but I admit I was startled quite a few times while playing -- enough to keep me on my toes, but not too much to make me anxious about playing.

Things I didn't like about the game? Well, there's not much to dislike, to be honest. I guess the speed at which the characters walk and climb objects is annoying, but a lot of the time, the dialogue fills in that space, and makes it less boring. The mechanics of the radio aren't super fun, either. It's an essential portion of the game, yet I had issues with the radio closing out when I was turning the dial, and making me repeat sequences of tunings over again. This, in itself, would be a harmless glitch if it didn't take forever to change the channel on the radio. It made discovering the anomalies" disinteresting to me since it just took so long to walk to the rocks and then tune the radio to the right station. But maybe I'm just too impatient.

reviewText: -soft-spoiler warning-\nOxenfree is a great game with a few concepts that makes it stand out , and i definitely recommend it, but i really wish there was more game. I wish there was so much Oxenfree i'd become completely sick of it. I dont mean to discourage the optimistic buyer because there is a lot of replay value for those of you who want to experience every nook and cranny of this game. In my honest opinion though, after playing through once and realizing the tragedy going on in the game i lost all interest in playing it again. Sadly, nothing really matter in the first place.

This is a fantastic game. My only complaint was that some of the character development was a little predictable. Still the story was great and by the end I was sad that it was over.

Just completed my first playthrough of the game, and I had an amazing time with it, the atmosphere was spot on without overdoing the spooky elements at all, and the overall sense of mystery and intrigue I got had me gripped from start to finish, I feel like Oxenfree would make a great novel but it also excels as a game, definitely worth playing!

Oxenfree is a great game and not too long that you can finish it in a couple of evenings. The voice work is great and the overall plot is lovely. Very quickly on I started having glitches with characters getting stuck, which occurred reguarly. This annoyingly meant replaying entire scenes because you only save on entering a new area.

Like many games where choosing options is supposed to affect the plot, this didn't feel like my choices really made that much of a difference - and indeed looking at the alterntive endings on YouTube, other than the final photo and dialogue changes - nothing really does.

Another gripe was that the radio transmissions were subtitled, and were by far the hardest things to hear. Finally, it felt like RUN button was very much needed as there is a lot of walking around and it felt like it took an eternity.

I see little replay value, but I would recommend it.

Relaxing and easy gameplay with an intriguing story.  It isn't a long game, but anymore, I feel too many devs work on making a LONG game for customers money rather than a GOOD game.  This game was as long as it needed to be.  It told the story, it held my interest, and it didn't leave a bad taste in my mouth after words.  Add the chance for different endings and a plot twist, and I'd say it's worth your money if you're already reading this far.

To kick things off, this game feels a lot like Life is Strange, if you haven't played that game yet, you should. This is one of those games that is just a big pile of ART. Like, the art style of the game sits well with me, beautiful, eerie, and haunting, pretty much the style that I like. There are choices in the game as you play as Alex, Telltale games style, and the ending is very open it makes you think.

I'll probably be playing more of this game after buying a new rig, it lags a bit in my old computer, but that doesn't take you away from the art and the WTF factor in the game or the thrills.

I went into this game totally blind, not knowing what the hell in store for me unlike most games where I usually read the reviews first, and it was the best decision I made after buying this game in my limited game budget.

I recommend this game for those who prefer good story to gameplay.

Love, love, loved this game. Some of the most believable characters I've ever seen in a game. Art was beautiful, acting was great, story was cool. Would've loved tougher puzzles but fantasitic overall

Oxenfree has a really interesting story, with supernatural and creepy elements. It takes place on a fairly small island, which you will explore as Alex with a few intriguing side characters. The dialogue between these characters is basically all this game has to offer outside of it's main story, as it's pretty much all you do in between the story progressions. Thankfully the dialogue is great, all the characters are interesting in their own way, although they feel a bit one dimensional at times.
The voice acting is great for the most part, I really enjoyed it during the random dialogue, but it fell short on some of the more serious situations, clearly lacking the emotion you'd expect.

The dialogue system works really well. It lets you choose between a few options and when to say it, in a limited time. It has been implemented well, so it feels a lot more like real conversations compared to most other games.

The main problem with the game is it's price. It only takes 4-6 hours to complete, and has limited replayability. Sure, there's a few times where you can bring a different companion, or say different things, but that's too far in between for my liking, not to mention the long walks with dialogue you've already heard once before.
That said, I do not regret buying this at almost full price, but if you're not super into the story telling games, then I'd recommend waiting for a sale.

Oxenfree has an interesting vibe about it, similar to a 1980's teenage horror ghost story movie, creepy without being graphic, and it's a style that suits the game and engine well. Without spoiling anything the story is pretty standard fare and nothing to really right home about, the graphical style is quirky and the sound design is very well done.

The game is basically a 2d walking simulator as it requires very little input from you the player to carry the story along, I've read comparisons to Telltale games but the story doesn't hold up to their usual standard.

If the game succeeds at one thing it's at atmosphere and creeping you out, it did genuinely raise a few hairs on the back of my neck at a few points.

I'd recommend the game in a sale for around £7.50 but I wouldn't personally say I got a £15 experiance from the game, besides the underused radio mechanic and interesting conversation mechanic the game is pretty mediocre and not one that will stick with me.

Imagine if the Nolan brothers made a game, this is like that. The story is outstanding, the game is solid, and I have only a few problems with it:

1. The AI pathing is shoddy at times, for some reason only one character can interact with certain paths at a time. It's a minor problem, but it hurts the immersion.

2. There are a lot of little things in the game you can notice, but the dialogue and plot push you to look past them. Again, a minor issue, but it feels like the devs want you to interact with everything and find the little hidden things and then the plot contradicts that.

3. The cool thing about the dialogue is that the options can interrupt NPC dialogue, it's a great idea, but as with most inventive ideas in the gaming industry, it's not executed perfectly. Occasionally, you will be forced to choose a dialogue option due to a time limit, even though you want to keep listening to the NPC's, or you'll press a dialogue option before an NPC starts speaking and you'll miss out that way. Good idea, decent execution. Again, only a minor detractor.

Essentially, this is a really good story driven game. It's somewhat short, but has replayability through its branching story. The dialogue has an interesting gimmick and the atmosphere is amazing.

tl;dr It's a short but great story game

Summary:
- Short, consider the price tag when buying
- Non-QWERTY users beware
- Great graphic style and voice acting
- Dialogue might take a bit of patience
- The ending.... ymmv

Definitely a short game - I extended it by exploring a lot and taking my time with conversations - so consider that with the price tag, but I enjoyed it a lot. Loved the graphic style and voice acting, and the story was really satisfying (although that's definitely going to be a subjective thing).

The dialogue system requires a bit of patience if you want to hear as much of the conversations as possible, and waiting too long sometimes means you miss the chance to make a dialogue choice since a lot of them are designed with the idea that no response is a valid option. Also, some choices will interrupt the conversation, others won't, and I didn't see anything that would indicate one way or another.
There's also a few points where the characters get really naggy if you don't instantly do a thing, even when you're already attempting to do the thing and it actually takes a few seconds to make it work. Or the game is a little slow to tell you what key you need to press.

Lack of key rebinding was a bit annoying. I use a Dvorak keyboard, and while it's not exactly hard to switch the layout to QWERTY it's really stupid that I had to.

Some people are going to find this replayable, others not so much, particularly if you explore and collect a lot in the first playthrough. I'd say any replays probably need to be done at about the same pace as the first to really build the story again.

Overall, I loved it, and I'll replay it again but not straight away. Like rereading a book, gotta let it settle a bit first.

Wow, really just wow. Between the great voice acting, creative story, and relatable characters, Oxenfree is a real gem, worthy of a few playthroughs.

The art style is quite nice, reminiscent of older animated movies and television shows from the late 90's and early 2000's. Backgrounds have a painted, rich feeling that really makes the map lovely to explore. The characters art is simple, but unique, drawing an image for the character, but not setting them into an archetype. This game is really wonderful to look at. The antagonist spirits appear as shadows, punctuated with partial red outline that gives them a certain alien feeling of wrongness. Overall the art sets the feeling of the game wonderfully and helps to draw in the player right off the bat.

The story and dialog are really inspired and very well done. At no point do the characters really become stereotypes, although a few characters aren't completely fleshed out, by the end. Exposition is carried out tastefully and naturally. Natural is actually a very good word for describing the majority of the dialog in the game, it feels normal, the conversations feel like conversations that real teenagers would have. Lately, some games with characters around this age have tried to shoehorn in pop culture references that often feel contrived and awkward. Oxenfree doesn't try this, opting to instead have the characters interact like normal people. Bolstered by some fantastic voice acting, the script is wonderful. The story is involving and smart, tying the characters together and moving forward at a good pace. Combined with optional collectibles scattered around the map, the story really builds the history of the island and surrounding towns into something memorable.

In terms of gameplay and puzzles, Oxenfree plays it simple and safe. Controls are basic, although traversing the map can get a little slow. The scenery is usually attractive enough to make the jogs between areas at worst acceptable, and at best a joy. The game is verging on being a walking simulator, with all of the puzzles being very simply moving the mouse left or right. Different dialog options and endings make the game's replayability high, along with finding all of the collectibles that aren't required, but help to complete the world.

The score for the game is fantastic, matching the mood perfectly, the soundtrack for this game goes up there with Transistor and Bastion as some of my favorite videogame music.

Without gathering collectibles, the game will take around 2-4 hours to complete for one playthrough, with another hour or so for gathering the collectibles. The game, in my opinion, deserves at least 2 full playthroughs, as there are many different possible endings and choices that can be made.

Tl;dr:

Pros:
-gorgeous art
-great voice acting
-wonderful story and dialog
-good atmosphere
-beautiful music

Cons:
-very simple puzzles
-slow movement makes for a little slogging

I absolutely love this game. It has likeable characters, clever dialogue, great voice acting, engaging story and atmosphere, beautiful art style, good soundtrack and smooth character animations. I also appreciate the fixed camera view which helps to capture the scenery very well. My only issue is the irregular movement speed. There's no separate run/sprint button, so you're pretty much stuck with whatever the main protagonist decides to do, whether she's jogging at a brisk pace or calmly strolling through the area, depending on how much dialogue is going on at the present time. I can forgive this, though, as it helps add to the story.

This game was an amazing surprise. I loved everything about it. I only played it once, but I feel like I missed so much (whether or not that is the case, I have no idea). The story is somewhat unique, and the mechanic used to interrupt conversation definitely forces you to stay focused on the narrative. The art style and animation is beautifully detailed. I definitely enjoyed it.

At first I was drawn by the art style of Oxenfree. I am a sucker for these kind of games. However I soon found out that the game has much more to offer then some pretty colors.

This game is a legit horror experience and a breath of fresh air from the walking simulator/ horror games we have been getting recently. It’s not the jump scares that gets you but the constant worry about the characters and what might happen to them. Speaking of character they were some of the best written teenagers in recent gaming history. After a few hours I got to know each characters well enough to give a ♥♥♥♥ if they die or live. Not only that but you have direct control over their relationships with one another throughout the game.

I can't not stress enough how good this game is. Great art, writing, story, characters and atmosphere. The game is worth every last penny of its price and I would have paid even more for this experience.

I really love the story and the gameplay! If you love anything interactive and adventure this game is for you~!

but so far that's all and I really love it! I would rate it 9/10 Play this game now~! It's worth it!

Overall, an intriguing story told in a way that you probably have not experienced before. Once is enough for me, but I am glad to have taken the chance on this one.

I bought Oxenfree out of curiosity, and after finishing the game I was left with new questions, awe, and an overall satisfactory experience under my belt.

Gameplay

The gameplay is simple, but very intuitive and fun. Walking around using WASD, using shift to control the radio, ctrl for map. While the game could have been a  point-and-click adventure, I felt that using WASD controls connected you a bit more to the characters. Quirky and spectacular moments hold other control schemes, but to give them away is to destroy the curiosity they deliver.

Plot

The plot is well laid out and flows well, never making dull moments take too long. I wasn't sure whether to classify this as a 'scary' game, as while I feel that there are definitely elements of horror within the game the relative atmosphere this gives off is much lighter. Characters continuously joke around, and in the end it feels more like an adventure that develops through teenage angst and determination to make their own decisions then anything extremely sinister. My one critique of the writing would be that several intense moments are followed by a half-hearted OH NO"
date: when a real person would be freaking out a lot more. Other then these specific moments
hoursPlayed:
the voice-overs are spot on and represent their character's very well.

Music

Music makes or breaks a game like this
voteText: and I am happy to say that SCNTFC did a great job putting the soundtrack together. Whether you're on a beach or a dark foreboding cave the sound design encapsulates the moments and pulls the player in. I would say more to praise the sound
helpfulPercent:
however this game heavily relies upon it and I would not like to spoil anything.

Overall

The game is a well rounded jaunt on an island full of secrets
