reviewText:
Summary:
- Short, consider the price tag when buying
- Non-QWERTY users beware
- Great graphic style and voice acting
- Dialogue might take a bit of patience
- The ending.... ymmv

Definitely a short game - I extended it by exploring a lot and taking my time with conversations - so consider that with the price tag, but I enjoyed it a lot. Loved the graphic style and voice acting, and the story was really satisfying (although that's definitely going to be a subjective thing).

The dialogue system requires a bit of patience if you want to hear as much of the conversations as possible, and waiting too long sometimes means you miss the chance to make a dialogue choice since a lot of them are designed with the idea that no response is a valid option. Also, some choices will interrupt the conversation, others won't, and I didn't see anything that would indicate one way or another.
There's also a few points where the characters get really naggy if you don't instantly do a thing, even when you're already attempting to do the thing and it actually takes a few seconds to make it work. Or the game is a little slow to tell you what key you need to press.

Lack of key rebinding was a bit annoying. I use a Dvorak keyboard, and while it's not exactly hard to switch the layout to QWERTY it's really stupid that I had to.

Some people are going to find this replayable, others not so much, particularly if you explore and collect a lot in the first playthrough. I'd say any replays probably need to be done at about the same pace as the first to really build the story again.

Overall, I loved it, and I'll replay it again but not straight away. Like rereading a book, gotta let it settle a bit first.

Very fun game. I really enjoyed how I could choose what to say to my friends. It gives you a sense that you are connecting more with the story. Also some parts were pretty...odd. In a great way. You can play the game more than a few times and still get fresh enjoyment everytime. Overall, I'm really happy I got this game.

A very cool adventure game with an inventive dialogue system. I finished my first run through in about four hours, but there are a lot of things you'll miss in a single playthrough and it's fun to try different options and hunt around for secret radio frequencies. If you're a fan of adventure games, talking, ham radio, mysteries, the paranormal, talking, the Pacific Northwest, island hijinks, or talking, then this one is for you.

I'm just about at the conclusion of the game, but I felt the need to write a review as I see this game as one that stands out as a singular experience in my gaming history. There's not anything quite like it. To compare it to teen horror flicks is a little bit of an injustice, and it is far from a simple adventure game. Your choices do matter in this game, and the dialogue with your compatriots in the mystery can affect their perception of you as a whole. The game indicates it in a simple but effective way, and you can see how the things your friends say can also come across with the others as well. I found myself reloading the game just to see how particular scenarios would play out, and I don't find myself in that place often. It really felt like a deep experience I could have mistaken for a AAA title, and in the most amazing way, it reminded me of the often imitated but seldom done well experience of a choose your own adventure book, particularly the memories I have of the Goosebumps choice novels I read growing up.\n\nThis game is well worth the money and I will be revisiting it to see what else my choices can change within the game's haunting world.

What can I say?

I was a little bit unsure at the very start of what to expect. I wasn't instantly captured and drawn in to be honest.

Don't let my first sentence put you off at all. After about the 15-20 minute mark, things began to get very interesting and take kind of a dark turn (without giving away too much).

From that moment on, I was literally engaged 100% until the end of the game.

Pros:

- Nice art style.
- I really loved the voice acting.
- Awesome story.
- Very user interactive with the conversations.
- Some nice humor.
- Makes you think.

Cons: (being very nitpicky)

- Sometimes there are chat bubbles you have to choose what to say but there isn't enough time unless you can read really fast and then process which one you want to choose, then click on it. A majority of the time I ended up not picking anything because they faded away before I had the chance to select one, plus I was also trying to listen to the rest of the conversation.
- It's a really easy game for unfortunate people like myself born with the 'gift' of 'derping' to totally make a mess of everything.

Overall, though, this game is really worth it to me. To an extent it has some replay value in a way. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this.

Oxenfree has a really interesting story, with supernatural and creepy elements. It takes place on a fairly small island, which you will explore as Alex with a few intriguing side characters. The dialogue between these characters is basically all this game has to offer outside of it's main story, as it's pretty much all you do in between the story progressions. Thankfully the dialogue is great, all the characters are interesting in their own way, although they feel a bit one dimensional at times.
The voice acting is great for the most part, I really enjoyed it during the random dialogue, but it fell short on some of the more serious situations, clearly lacking the emotion you'd expect.

The dialogue system works really well. It lets you choose between a few options and when to say it, in a limited time. It has been implemented well, so it feels a lot more like real conversations compared to most other games.

The main problem with the game is it's price. It only takes 4-6 hours to complete, and has limited replayability. Sure, there's a few times where you can bring a different companion, or say different things, but that's too far in between for my liking, not to mention the long walks with dialogue you've already heard once before.
That said, I do not regret buying this at almost full price, but if you're not super into the story telling games, then I'd recommend waiting for a sale.

I managed to get this game on sale, for a decent price, thinking it would be a fun little adventure game. While I can safely say that i got what I was expecting, this game is well worth it's full price!

You play as Alex, a young girl who is spending the night with some friends on a small island, that once housed a military base. Armed with a radio, you accidently open a mysterious gift, that unleashes ghosts from the past. Now, it's up to you, to survive the night, find your friends, and escape the growing nightmare!

While I can't say it's the most graphically impressive Indie game i've played, it manages to have some great artwork, that matches the style and gameplay. The characters are all very good, and portrayed with great voice acting. the story itself manages to remain genuinely interesting throught, despite some cliche's sprinkled throught. While I won't spoil the ending, I can say, that I had a genuine sense of satisfaction with the ending, and seeing that my choices had real impact.

The only blatant negative's that I can find, are that it can be slow at times, with how fast the character's move around the map, but that was solved with some very well written dialogue, and some heartfelt characters moments. The worst thing for me, was that the game can bug out sometimes, leading one to restart an area over again.

All in all, I have to say that Oxenfree" is a truly great game

Absolutely reccommend! The art style is beautiful, the soundtrack is gorgeous, the story is rich, and the characters feel like real people. The radio mechanic is cool as well and adds suspense and tension to the game when you have to tune in to a certain frequency. There's replay value here as well; without spoiling too much, your dialogue choices have far reaching consequences in-game.

If you love games like Life is Strange (story-telling games, that is), you will fall in love with this one too. It's spooky, but I never found myself so scared that I wanted to turn off the game. It has an absolutely stunning art style. The story is wonderful (along with the characters). The ending is nice too! If you play it, one word of advice: Pay attention. And have fun, of course!
I really like this game and  I would definetly recomend it.

Cool game. Great story with brilliant voice acting.

My gripes are two:

1. The text bubbles are white font with light green backgrounds - making them very hard to read. In situations where you sometimes have to react quickly, this is a huge annoyance which shouldn't even be a problem. Black font would have fixed this; no idea why they chose to make the text white.

2. This one may just be me, but I would have appreciated a zoom feature. Being able to get a close up of the characters and backgrounds would be a nice feature. The wide shots are great for establishing the scenery, but I just want to zoom in every once in awhile to get a closer look.

Other than those two things, this is a superb game. A bit short with only a 4-hour playtime, but that's probably for the best - keeps the narrative tight and without needless fetch-quests and item hunts.

Definitely recommend this to anyone who likes story and dialogue heavy games.
Great thriller, Awesome plot, And overall a great game to play! It keeps you on your toes! And it's so Awesome! I really hope there's a second part of this!! :D

This game was absolutely beautiful and is filled with many mysteries that'll keep you interested in the game as you play. Definitely a game worth buying during a sale, but the $20.00 price tag is a little high if you ask me.\n\n8/10

This game makes me feel like I'm playing a video game again. An actual solid, well thought out, immersive, greatly detailed video game. The idea of the core gameplay itself is refreshing and flatout brilliant in its execution. Memorable characters with excellent voice actors that get lost in the world of their roles (always a plus), great level design, solid and easy to understand gameplay mechanics, an atmosphere that draws me in, an amazing soundtrack, and a storyline that keeps me guessing and wanting to continue on my journey - all of these aspects has probably put this game into my top 10 games of all time. Maybe even my top 5!

Seriously, for such a simple game, yet with such a complex and brilliant presentation, it EASILY competes with many games that have been developed by big name developers and publishers out there. It's masterful is what it is! Well, maybe not masterful. There's this latency issue where the game slows down and lags for some odd reason. Whether this is an optimization error or what, I have no idea. Thankfully, it doesn't happen too often and it might be just an issue on my end. But that's not my main gripe.

My main gripe is the multi-choice character dialogue. When I choose a statement the character says something that isn't what I was expecting. As I result I keep reloading the scenes just to choose the one I intended. It has the BioWare thing going on. But that's minor compared to the true brilliance of this game; brilliance that I am about to reveal to you.

Unlike BioWare and their games like Mass Effect and Dragon Age (or any game with multiple choice dialogue), in Oxenfree, when you're in a conversation, your response can just be... nothing... NOTHING. ABSOLUTELY NOTHING! YES! THANK YOU, OXENFREE! For once when characters are bickering with each other I can just stay quiet and reserve my responses! I don't have to choose an option! I don't have to force my character's input on others! And that's why I love this game so much! My overall involvment, or lack there of, feels so much more real and engaging for me when I can just listen a conversation out and add my input in when it is necessary! Absolutely GENIUS!!!

A big ol' 10/10, would buy another copy and give to a friend!

reviewText: I enjoyed playing Oxenfree, sad when it started closing to an end DDD:

Loved this game. As soon as I started watching a play through for this on YouTube I had to search it out. I knew it would be my kind of game and I was right. I don't know why a lot of people were saying that the kids in the game were annoying, I found them to be quite normal and if you didn't choose to play the game as a nasty person, then the conversations and interactions were enjoyable.

I really didn't want this game to end. It looks beautiful, I found myself wishing that I had created something like this myself. It had a magical feel which had an honestly creepy element as well. The story was intriguing, and I could have played for hours. Even though you had to travel through the same parts of the map a few times, there was always enough going on to make it different each time so these repeats didn't feel tedious or played out.

I'm now waiting a while so I can forget some of the gameplay in order for me to go back in and try playing differently. Maybe not be so nice of a character this time and see how that goes. I can't wait to see what the developers come up with after this. Very exciting to see such an original game, with a fantastic story, and what felt like real life interactions between friends.

This was my first point-and-click style game. I instantly fell in love with the characters and atmosphere of the game. The dialogue and acting from all the voice actors is excellent. Playing through this felt like watching a movie or reading a really good book.

As far as the horror/suspense aspect of the game - Some of the choices you're presented with are very difficult. You have to make a lot of split-second decisions that impact your friend's in the game that feel agonizing because you get sucked into the creepy ambience of the story.

The only thing I had a hard time with in this game was getting a little lost because you can't access the map in the middle of scenarios. For the directionally challenged like myself, this was a pain. I had to go back and forth a few times to get my bearing on the island. But having to backtrack helped me find more of the secrets...so, I guess it worked it in the end. :P

The game is very good, interesting and pretty.\nBut the glitch with the game thinking that you completed current task if you accidentaly leave the location - is not cool. Its not cool at all. As a result I can't complete final task at all. I can leave the island, sure, but I'm missing a big piece of content. You could've at least let us load previous saves, devs. Not cool.

This is one of the best games I've ever played. It's atmospheric horror that makes you care deeply about the characters. reviewText:
Oxenfree got me by the guts. The main story is not that scary but pushes you to be ever so curious and pay attention to details (and there's a lot). It reminds me of Life Is Strange in the way it treats its main character and her choices.
With its great dialogue options and magical voice acting, Oxenfree successfully makes the main characters loveable (it managed the uneasy task of making me want a happy ending for them ).
Overall, Oxenfree has a great ambiance and a cool soundtrack.
I highly recommand this for people who like story driven short games and promise a great experience!
This game was aweose! it got me on the edge of the chair all game long. Still it's to take the decision through the game, that why is awesome

Fun, creepy game with a nice story.  Easy to recommend.

This thrilling game is largely story based. The way you interact with other characters is very cool. You should play this game if you are looking for an interesting story. While this game does have hints of horror aspects, you should not play this if you are just looking for a horror game. The effects are freaky but I personally was not terrified by this game, but I still highly reccomend it because the story and characters & character development is awesome. Also I really enjoy the art style

The rich art, dialog, and storyline make this so much more then an interactive story. The game flows so well you forget that your playing and feel more you've jumped into a choose your own adventure novel.\n\nThe characters, the setting, and the mystery all cause a compelling story which is a must finish in one setting. I couldn't stop thinking about it when I was away.

DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Oxenfree amazed me the first time I saw it announced at E3 and I continued following it's development until I finally bought it and I was not dissapointed!

Oxenfree follows the story of five young teenagers who venture to a mysterious island for a few drinks and gossip, however, they soon find out the mysteries to this island. The story is extremely well written, so much so that I played the whole game from start to finish, very rare for me and only for games with good stories. The character development for each character is superb

The game is more like an interactive movie where you choose your dialogue and see the outcome, There is little interaction as in puzzles and most of the time it's just you moving about the island. The dialogue system is really good and innovative however the only complaint I'd have is that if you select a choice whilst another character is talking, then it immediately becomes overidden with the dialogue you chose

Visually the game is stunning and built on the Unity engine, this game amazed me to bits. The music as well was perfect and fitted so well with the atmosphere of the game and the sci-fi genre. The voice acting was also superb and each character had their own personality and made the characters even more believable

Oxenfree is a fantastic interactive movie game that everyone should give a go! It's innovative and original!

Excellent mood, a fleshed out setting, and charming kids.
(Narrative is a key point for the enjoyment you’ll get out of this game, and I’m going to spoil some of it in order to talk about and critique it. You’ve been warned.)

The very best way I can think to describe Oxenfree, is that it feels kind of like a Telltale game got mixed up with or influenced by an 80’s teen horror flick like Poltergeist or what have you. Except, unlike a Telltale game, Night School Studio isn’t stoking the flames under six other games at the same time, so it doesn’t feel near as half-baked. You play the snarky blue-haired girl, Alex. She and her friends, Ren, Jonas, Nona, and Clarissa, are all high school students living in a scenic coastal town. Together they head to a small tourist trap of an island just offshore to less than legally spend the night there for a party, as is a time-honored tradition for upperclassmen. The intent is to drink, dance, and be merry, but before anyone can get good and properly drunk, they are plagued by mysterious forces beyond their understanding or control, awoken by a small portable radio Alex is carrying around.

Probably one of the best things Oxenfree understands is its sense of pacing. It’s all good and well that I came here to be spooked by otherworldly forces, but you’ve got to set the mood first. You spend the first twenty minutes or so fiddling with the game’s dialogue options and getting to know its meager cast of five characters. Some might find it a little on the boring side, but it’s the perfect lull to make the creepy events later on feel all the more jarring. It’s also a pretty good introduction to the characters, each of whom at first glance might seem to fill a specific tropey role for this exact brand of narrative. But very quickly they spend this early game time filling in; there’s a good few backstories and anecdotes getting told that paint them with decent personality beyond simple labels. And with one of the characters being new to the group, it doesn’t feel out of place at all. This also very efficiently sets up where everybody stands with everybody else. One of my personal favorite things about the characters though, is that they feel like believable angsty teens. There’s none of that “how do you do, fellow kids” nonsense like with Life is Strange where the writers tried and failed so miserably to mimic hip kid lingo, which can really take you out of the experience. It all at the very least starts to form that all important attachment to the characters so that you’ll actually be invested and give half a care when the potentially life-threatening hauntings start happening. Suffice it to say, tone is established pretty darn well, and without feeling like the game is wasting any of your time doing so.

Speaking of believability, though, the setting also feels very fully realized. There’s a rich history to the island that you can access at certain spots via your radio, and it breathes a lot of life into the setting, helping greatly with immersion. You can sit down and listen to it at your leisure, and I really suggest you do. Without wishing to give away too much, one of the puzzles in the game involves trivia about the island. Aside from that and one other puzzle, though, the rest of the gameplay mostly consists of the same puzzle over and over again, if you can even call it a puzzle. You just mozey Alex on up next to whatever object the plot has grabbed hold of, and have her tune the radio until the plot sorts itself out. Gameplay, I’ll be honest, is where Oxenfree is at its most lacking. At the same time though, it’s a certain type of game that people simply aren’t drawn to for the actual play of the game. But if you’re not into games of that nature, Oxenfree probably isn’t going to change your mind.

Perhaps Oxenfree’s second most lacking point is that of narrative agency for the player. Not that it’s terribly lacking; there are a good few hidden factors in the moment-to-moment dialogue options that’ll affect certain things later on. But it’s lacking where it feels it should matter most. Shortly after the inciting incident, Alex and Jonas are faced with a true to form Telltale esque major decision, in which friend to go save first. I figured, during my initial playthrough, that my decision would ultimately affect which of them had a worse time during the plot. But after playing again, I found the events happen in the same exact way, just in a different order. I can’t help but feel let down, because if choosing favorites doesn’t mean others taking the brunt of the hauntings, then what is even the point? That’s not to say the game is totally bereft of alternate story scenarios, which it definitely has. But none of it seems to come up until the tail end. Maybe all of this matters later, but why can’t it matter now? Why set it up as though it does matter right now, if it doesn’t? It feels a little dishonest by design.

Another saving grace, though, is something else Oxenfree understands pretty well, at least, definitely better than something like Firewatch. It’s that, if you’re going to write a character who, let’s be honest, only exists to add a sympathetic note to one of the other characters, while that’s all good and well, you’ll paint a fuller picture if you broaden your brushstrokes to actually include said vestigial character. What I mean is, Henry from Firewatch had Julia, but she was defined almost entirely by her profession and her relationship to Henry. Oxenfree’s counter to this is Alex’s dead brother Michael. During the home stretch, Oxenfree  has several flashback sequences where the player controls Alex during fond memories involving her brother. Everytime he comes up though, he’s buzzing with ideas about the direction he wants to take his life in. A lot of this affects Alex, obviously, but a lot of other things he mentions don’t have anything to do with her. It broadens him into feeling more like his own character, as opposed to purely being a reason for you to feel sorry for Alex. Unlike with Julia, it’s because not everything about him was mentioned or shown simply because of how sad it was going to make Alex.

On the whole, it has its little quirks and issues here and there. It’s definitely not a perfect game. If you can’t get past the character models looking like tiny dolls, or you’re just not into this type of game, you’re probably not going to enjoy it. And I’ll admit, the overall scariness was hit and miss, and the mundanity of the explanation behind the hauntings was a little disappointing. But all together, I’d say Oxenfree is a pretty solid little game. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives by a longshot. The tone, setting, and characters are all really well thought out and executed. Ultimately, those alone are enough to call it a satisfying overall experience.

Fantastic story, with great writing and some of the best voice acting I've heard in a game. It's also beautiful to look at and the mix of huge 2d scenery with the small 3d characters works well with the exploration-based gameplay. You basically just wander around an island and tune a radio to different frequencies but the story and characters are captivating and there is a really neat surprise at the very end. My only complaint is that sometimes it takes a while to backtrack somewhere because the characters walk so slowly, but these walking parts are usually filled with conversations between the characters.

The game only took me a few hours to complete but it felt like the perfect length. Highly, highly recommend.

I recommend this one if you like a good story with a lot of choices on the way.

The biggest drawbacks are
- there are no real puzzles
- traveliing to a different area takse too much time

It is unbelievably beautiful, the story is engaging, the characters are loveable and relatable, the horror elements gives a couple thrills. The voice actors' work is just splendid. For the fans of the genre or just those who don't mind those walking/talking simulators (with, dare I say, excellent dialogue) this is a must-have.\n\n9.5/10.

I really didn't want this game to end. It looks beautiful, I found myself wishing that I had created something like this myself. It had a magical feel which had an honestly creepy element as well. The story was intriguing, and I could have played for hours. Even though you had to travel through the same parts of the map a few times, there was always enough going on to make it different each time so these repeats didn't feel tedious or played out.

I'm now waiting a while so I can forget some of the gameplay in order for me to go back in and try playing differently. Maybe not be so nice of a character this time and see how that goes. I can't wait to see what the developers come up with after this. Very exciting to see such an original game, with a fantastic story, and what felt like real life interactions between friends.

The idea is neat, the story is great, but the HUGE lag between characters talking is obnoxious. For example, the character is asked his name is Jonas not Jonah, then he waits 15 seconds before answering the question, like he needed to consider it... it is almost mood killing when the the conversations dont feel smooth.

Well done. The story was compelling and well thought. The game mechanics were interesting and unique without being cumbersome. Dialog was entertaining but at times dialog options vanished a bit too fast.

Oh dear. This game. I am in love. Now in my 3rd time playing it, I am utterly obsessed. It's story rich, innovative, and strikingly beautiful. I love horror games. I love story driven games even more. This game flawlessly blends the two into a great walk and talk game that's more than what you think. Each time you play can be different. Save Michael, make everyone hate you, etc, etc. With multiple endings, and dialogue that is impacted by what you choose to say, each time you play is interesting and exciting. The new update changes things from the get go. There's more dialogue, more story, and all new things to discover. Oxenfree is exciting, entancing, and something that will leave you reeling when you finish. I highly recommend this game, and definitely worth every penny.
Pros:
-Story Rich
-Beautiful Artistry
-Believable dialogue with incredible voice actors
-An absolute wonderful soundtrack
-Multiple endings/paths that allow you to play over and over
-Enjoyable Characters
Cons:
-I have an intense fear of White Noise, something that is a constant.
-A few isues with slow walking (a bit better in the update)
-Jonas glitches hardcore at one point. (Might be fixed in update, haven't gotten far enough)

First off, this is a awesome game. Normally I'm not one to play anything in the horror genre, but this was surprisingly good.\nGreat story line, awesome characters. Over all, a really solid game. The only downside is how quickly you can finish it. My first playthrough took about 3 hours. I will seriously be playing this again, because it has the potential for multiple endings and there is a lot more to explore than I did the first time. If you're looking for a decent game, take a chance and try Oxenfree out.

This game is a mesmerizing trip via a quirky story. It has fear, mystique and emotions in it and is one of the few games that draws you in and makes you care about the characters in the game.

Voice acting is superb as well.

This is how interactive stories should look like :)

Better than firewatch IMHO.

Definately worth to buy. (Well, at least at 14,99€. 20€ is a bit too much, but hey, I'm a schmuck from Lithuania, not the richest country in the world!)
